subject: Add optional token bind information to identity-api.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 4, 'name': 'Dolph Mathews', 'email': 'dolph.mathews@gmail.com', 'username': 'dolph'}, {'_account_id': 220, 'name': 'Haneef Ali', 'email': 'haneef.ali@hp.com', 'username': 'haneef'}, {'_account_id': 994, 'name': 'Arvind Tiwari', 'email': 'arvindt7@gmail.com', 'username': 'arvind-tiwari'}, {'_account_id': 1916, 'name': 'Guang Yee', 'email': 'gyee@suse.com', 'username': 'guang-yee'}, {'_account_id': 2218, 'name': 'Adam Young', 'email': 'adam@younglogic.com', 'username': 'ayoung'}, {'_account_id': 5707, 'name': 'henry-nash', 'email': 'henry.nash@uk.ibm.com', 'username': 'henry-nash'}, {'_account_id': 6460, 'name': 'Brad Topol', 'email': 'btopol@us.ibm.com', 'username': 'btopol'}, {'_account_id': 6486, 'name': 'Brant Knudson', 'email': 'blk@acm.org', 'username': 'blk-u'}, {'_account_id': 7191, 'name': 'Jamie Lennox', 'email': 'jamielennox@gmail.com', 'username': 'jamielennox'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-09 04:23:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/36166/1/check/gate-noop/3449 : SUCCESS in 0s
'}, {'account_id': 220, 'date': '2013-07-09 04:58:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Can you please add more information?  A proper usage pattern for client certs."}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-07-09 05:08:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I haven't referenced an example for client certificates because at the moment we don't have a client cert auth mechanism. 

My though would be that we would have a provider called 'x509' but within that could be either serial & issuer or fingerprint or anything else. I'm hoping to avoid specifying what the data will be in the bind information and leave that up to the bind providers. Whilst principal is the most logical thing to put in the kerberos bind provider you could theoretically fingerprint your token or something and use that as bind data if the provider supports it."}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-07-09 18:04:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-07-10 00:41:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-10 00:52:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/36166/2/check/gate-noop/3493 : SUCCESS in 0s
'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-07-10 01:05:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-10 01:16:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/36166/3/check/gate-noop/3496 : SUCCESS in 2s
'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-07-10 02:26:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-07-10 02:28:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-10 02:32:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/36166/4/check/gate-noop/3500 : SUCCESS in 0s
'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-07-10 16:54:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 220, 'date': '2013-07-10 17:22:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Can you please explain, how the  OS client can use this bind information?"}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-07-10 23:13:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

This is not information that clients are expected to consume. They will have to pass a config option to keystone to enable kerberos for example but we are trying to get that standardized so that the whole process should be transparent to the client. 

Bind enforcement is handled when talking to keystone or when going through auth_token_middleware.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-07-11 16:06:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

if API end users have no use for this information, then why is it included in the token? it smells like middleware.auth_token (or whatever) should be reaching back out to keystone to ask if an X-Subject-Token has any additional bind parameters that should be enforced.

  GET /v3/auth/tokens/OS-TOKEN-BIND/bind
  X-Subject-Token: {token}

response:

  Vary: X-Subject-Token

  { "bind": {"kerberos": { ... } }'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-07-12 00:00:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Keystone is saying that this token is only to be used with these external credentials. It has to be in the signed part of a PKI token to prove that it came from keystone.

If we make auth_token_middleware call back to keystone on every request to enquire about the bind status then we add a request to keystone to every (uncached) token validation. Not having this request is largely the point of PKI tokens. 

We could embed a flag in a token which says this token has bind information, go fetch it, but that is still modifying the token structure and would require having a url for where to fetch from and is at least as complicated as just storing the bind info. 

It's not a problem if the clients want to read from it, if they want to use it as part of their auth strategy but that should be statically configured anyway. It's just that it is really only relevant to auth_token_middleware."}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-07-12 00:27:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

PKI or UUID, Keystone tokens are not really a guarantee of identity, they are merely a statement of authorization attributes.  IN order for the Keystone token to be trusted, it needs to be linked to a secure authentication mechanism.  With a PKI token, the bind data allows it to be linked to Kerberos or to X509 client certs.  That gives the end service a complete chain of attributes they can trust, from identity down to the role assignments.  Without this binding, a stole token can be used to impersonate a user.  With this mechanism, that is no longer possible.


The auth_token middleware changes are dependant on this change.'}, {'account_id': 220, 'date': '2013-07-12 03:26:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Just one more question.

As a client, what should I do to get the bind information? e.g I get role information in the token, if I have a role assignment. Similarly some action has to be done for that user, so that, the user's token has bind information. What is that?  Are we supposed to have bind details like user's fingerprints populated in user table."}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-07-12 04:20:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

So the work to be done by the client is handled in auth_token_middleware which all clients should (and do) use to verify there tokens. If it passes through the middleware then the token is valid and can be used in the same way as before. 

The corresponding middleware part isn't up for review yet as it doesn't make sense until this is merged. 

If you really want to access this data it would be available in the token hash as this patch describes, but again stressing that the client side binding is completely handled by the time the token gets to the client application. There should be no reason to store or check anything."}, {'account_id': 220, 'date': '2013-07-13 18:16:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

You need to mention that this stuff works only if the entity is authenticated using external auth.  That's where the confusion comes."}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-07-15 00:20:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-15 00:20:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/36166/5/check/gate-noop/3670 : SUCCESS in 0s
'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-07-15 23:49:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-07-16 04:38:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-16 04:38:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/36166/6/check/gate-noop/3694 : SUCCESS in 0s

just a nit, also curious about the "may be" vs "must be" thing gyee mentioned'}, {'account_id': 6460, 'date': '2013-07-16 19:10:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
Add optional token bind information to identity-api.

Bind information is a dictionary keyed by the mechanism identifier with
a value containing data that is specific to that mechanism.

Required for bp authentication-tied-to-token

Change-Id: I8950540c14d61eecdac4014899a5a69bdcdcc319

commit_message:
Add Support for Rabbit Mirrored (HA) Queues

Previously, the nova::rabbitmq class could take advantage of
clustering, but mirrored (HA) queues would not behave properly
due to the version of RabbitMQ server installed.

Rabbit mirrored queues had several bugs that were fixed in 2.8.7:
  https://www.rabbitmq.com/release-notes/README-2.8.7.txt

This change will allow rabbit mirrored queues to behave properly
by installing the correct rabbitmq-server version.

Defaults to false to disable the use of rabbitmq-server version 2.8.7
and preservce backwards compatibility.

Change-Id: Iaeebb97c3437e5d610c606925a219e1c9949ae87

Fix the argument of UnknownArgument exception

This change sets the real UnknownArgument instead of the last
valid one in the exception raised by the API.

Fixes bug #1201839

Connection in ceilometer/storage/impl_mongodb.py

ensure_index() is used rather than create_index() to be more efficient.

This index is needed because get_samples() in
ceilometer/storage/impl_mongodb.py sorts by descending timestamp.  Without an

commit_message:
Add index for db.meter by descending timestamp

Fixes bug #1193906

Added an index for db.meter to sort by descending time stamp for class
Connection in ceilometer/storage/impl_mongodb.py

ensure_index() is used rather than create_index() to be more efficient.

This index is needed because get_samples() in
ceilometer/storage/impl_mongodb.py sorts by descending timestamp.  Without an
index, MongoDB will fail to sort if the database is too large.

Change-Id: I23070f153ce03a8d6d8c9f17f05e2d5dae38647e

commit_message:
Add an option to run_stress.py to run tests serially.

This commit adds a new option to run_stress.py to run the stress
tests serially. If more there is more than one JSON test in the
file passed into run_stress.py it would by default run the tests
in parallel. However, there was no way to specify running the tests
serially. This commit fixes this by adding a -s/--serial option
which will run each test to completion before launching the next
one.

Part of: blueprint stress-tests

Change-Id: I7188929485e29a761327ab24e2bb1213fbd052a9

commit_message:
Fix tox job for stress tests.

This commit fixes the behavior of the tox stress job. To do this a
new json tests file was added for the tox job. This json file will
contain a list of all the actions that will get run as part of the
tox job. (and by extension the periodic jenkins stress test job) The
tox job is then updated to run each of the tests listed in the json
file for an hour each.

Part of: blueprint stress-tests

Change-Id: I5eb0652799601631e34cc2bbef836624d71bb3e7

(7 inline comments)

I voted with -1 because of the super() signature difference.

Generally I am ok with this change.

I have some naming style note inline.
The module naming capital/lower case pep8 guideline is followed almost everywhere, it should be followed by the stress test as well.

testObject.testObject / test_object.TestObject.


I am ok with TestObject name, just the upper/lower case thing what I do not really like.
 
In-order to be less confusing with the usual unittests, it
can be named as StressJob or StressWorker or StressAction or just Action, (it may contain the Base or Abstract word.)

What do you think ?

(One additional note, python abstract class can be implemented in an __init__.py as well. I do not have preference here. )"}, {'account_id': 7872, 'date': '2013-07-12 10:30:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-12 00:24:40.000000000', 'message': "Rework stress to be more UnitTest like

This patch reworks the stress test framework and
the scripts to be a bit more flexible and to be
like how unit tests are written.  Instead of
writing a module that contains functions, we now
write an object that can implement a setUp and tearDown
method.  By default the object's 'run' method will be
called by the driver.

The setUp method will be called prior to calling run
and tearDown will be called after run is stopped.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I39b8a1d38f70ddda4867126b58bb7053b45654d6

commit_message:
Rework stress to be more UnitTest like

This patch reworks the stress test framework and
the scripts to be a bit more flexible and to be
like how unit tests are written.  Instead of
writing a module that contains functions, we now
write an object that can implement a setUp and tearDown
method.  By default the object's 'run' method will be
called by the driver.

The setUp method will be called prior to calling run
and tearDown will be called after run is stopped.

Also added debug logging to the cleanup mechanism.
Also added removing snapshots prior to removing
volumes during cleanup

DocImpact

Implements:  blueprint stress-tests

Change-Id: I39b8a1d38f70ddda4867126b58bb7053b45654d6

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-10 19:41:30.000000000', 'message': 'Adds multiple iSCSI port support

Added support to the 3PAR iSCSI OpenStack driver to provide the
ability to select the best fit target iSCSI port from a list of
candidate ports. The first time a volume is attached to a host,
all iSCSI ports configured for driver selection, are examined for
best fit. The port with the least active volumes attached will
then be selected as the path to the 3PAR array. Any subsequent
volume attach, to the same host, will use the established target
port.

Fixes but #1197036

Change-Id: Icf8c28ea3f201e5e21c9a6ed00a2fbdda445c8b3

commit_message:
Adds multiple iSCSI port support to 3PAR

Added support to the 3PAR iSCSI OpenStack driver to provide the
ability to select the best fit target iSCSI port from a list of
candidate ports. The first time a volume is attached to a host,
all iSCSI ports configured for driver selection, are examined for
best fit. The port with the least active volumes attached will
then be selected as the path to the 3PAR array. Any subsequent
volume attach, to the same host, will use the established target
port.

DocImpact

Fixes bug #1197036

Change-Id: Icf8c28ea3f201e5e21c9a6ed00a2fbdda445c8b3

commit_message:
Move a migration test to MigrationTestCase.

There is test_migration_get_unconfirmed_by_dest_compute
test in old mixed DbApiTestCase. This patch moves this test
to its native test case MigrationTestCase.

DbApiTestCase renamed as DecoratorTestCase because no
db api methods tests remained in this test case.

blueprint db-api-tests

Change-Id: Ibe6ebf266a2f4694fb218266ba644be825889907

commit_message:
Add a new GroupAffinityFilter

1) Add a new filter to schedule the instance on to host from a set
   of group hosts
2) Update filter_scheduler.rst to add the new GroupAffinityFilter
   filter description

Implements blueprint group-affinity-filter

DocImpact

Change-Id: Iba59764e692cd1d3bc80521ba5a4412f2bebb168

Allow access to
 - Metadata API (8775)
 - Neutron API  (9696)
 - AMQP         (5672)

Deny access to dhcp, specific MAC's are granted access by
elements/nova-baremetal/bin/filter-bootps

Change-Id: If2af136caaa28a6553f3f0579c91aa53a6dfb74e
"}]
commit_message:
Fedora firewall changes

Allow access to
 - Metadata API (8775)
 - Neutron API  (9696)
 - AMQP         (5672)

Deny access to dhcp, specific MAC's are granted access by
elements/nova-baremetal/bin/filter-bootps

Change-Id: If2af136caaa28a6553f3f0579c91aa53a6dfb74e

'}, {'created': '2013-07-16 18:22:31.000000000', 'message': 'feat(storage): do not restrict the container type

In Python, container is a concept, not a specific type.  The original
implementation limit the container to list, while this change allow you
to use other containers, like tuple, to supply as a sequence of the
message IDs.

Change-Id: I347e764ed0e965f17aa49f3e80f2f100ba8ba495
'}]
commit_message:
feat(storage): do not restrict the container type

In Python, container is a concept, not a specific type.  The original
implementation limit the container to list, while this change allow you
to use other containers, like tuple, to supply as a sequence of the
message IDs.

Change-Id: I347e764ed0e965f17aa49f3e80f2f100ba8ba495

What version of jsonschema does this patch require? I just synched up on the latest glance and now this test is failing in tempest:

https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/api/image/v2/test_images.py#L45

It was failing with schema validation errors. I noticed that I was using jsonschema 0.7.  The pip-requires in glance and requirements.txt in tempest list jsonschema as a dependency but don't pin a version.  When I updated to jsonschema 1.3, the schema validation error in tempest went away."}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-07-16 23:24:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Matt Riedemann, I'm using v1.1.0 locally. You can query that from above Jenkins verify result log (and which was passed): http://logs.openstack.org/35134/14/gate/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/31917/console.html.gz"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-01 13:37:16.000000000', 'message': 'Add/remove/replace locations from an image

This patch modifies the PATCH /v2/images/{id} API call. Clients can add,
remove and replace locations from the set of multiple locations
associated with a given image ID in the following way:

PATCH /images/1234
[{"op": "add", "path": "/locations/-", "value": "scheme3://path3"}]
PATCH /images/1234
[{"op": "add", "path": "/locations/1", "value": "scheme4://path4"}]
PATCH /images/1234
[{"op": "remove", "path": "/locations/2"}]
PATCH /images/1234
[{"op": "replace", "path": "/locations", "value": []}]
PATCH /images/5678
[{"op": "replace", "path": "/locations", "value": ["scheme5://path5",
"scheme6://path6"]}]

Glance will check location correctness when client adding, and will
remove the image content from the store when client remove a location.

Implement bp: multiple-image-locations

commit_message:
Add/remove/replace locations from an image

This patch modifies the PATCH /v2/images/{id} API call. Clients can add,
remove and replace locations from the set of multiple locations
associated with a given image ID in the following way:

PATCH /images/1234
[{"op": "add", "path": "/locations/-",
  "value": {"url": "scheme3://path3", "metadata": {}}}]
PATCH /images/1234
[{"op": "add", "path": "/locations/1",
  "value": {"url": "scheme4://path4", "metadata": {}}}]
PATCH /images/1234
[{"op": "remove", "path": "/locations/2"}]
PATCH /images/1234
[{"op": "replace", "path": "/locations", "value": []}]
PATCH /images/5678
[{"op": "replace", "path": "/locations",
  "value": [{"url": "scheme5://path5", "metadata": {}},
            {"url": "scheme6://path6", "metadata": {}}]}]

Glance will check location correctness when client adding, and will
remove the image content from the store when client remove a location.

Implement bp: multiple-image-locations
docimpact

Change-Id: I845646fde22e18be27929b5ec70ef8041b6fa733
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

Determine hot template and display yaml format for it, display json
format for others.

Fixes: bug #1201482

commit_message:
Fix nova-bm-dnsmasq.service

[/usr/lib/systemd/system/nova-bm-dnsmasq.service:9] Unknown lvalue
'-ExecStartPre' in section 'Service'

Adding a - to ExecStartPre causes systemd to ignore
the exit code but the "-" was in the wrong place.

Change-Id: I2a62f48b307f09aa23603d97066e6a1c9c76135f

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-16 23:13:28.000000000', 'message': "Fedora 19 GRUB

In the 52-force-text-mode-console hook, gracefully exit when the
/boot/grub2 directory does not exist on the Fedora 19 cloud image
filesystem. By default the Fedora 19 cloud image is using extlinux to boot
the image instead of GRUB. The decision was taken because GRUB is quite
big (would pull in ~30MB of dependencies) and there's very little benefit
in using it because cloud images don't need to cover all the corner cases.

Change-Id: I52723d4d14c21b1787b4c7e0dd21a09cdbdae0d1
"}]
commit_message:
Fedora 19 GRUB

In the 52-force-text-mode-console hook, gracefully exit when the
/boot/grub2 directory does not exist on the Fedora 19 cloud image
filesystem. By default the Fedora 19 cloud image is using extlinux to boot
the image instead of GRUB. The decision was taken because GRUB is quite
big (would pull in ~30MB of dependencies) and there's very little benefit
in using it because cloud images don't need to cover all the corner cases.

Change-Id: I52723d4d14c21b1787b4c7e0dd21a09cdbdae0d1

commit_message:
Limit min<=max port check to TCP/UDP in secgroup rule

icmp_type and icmp_code are mapped to port_min_range and port_max_range
respectively. For ICMP there is no constraint between type and code.
Thus port range min<=max check should be enforced only for TCP and UDP.

Also makes sure that ICMP type/code are 0 to 255 (both inclusive).
Previously a value with 0 to 65535 were accepted for ICMP type/code.

Fixes bug 1197760
Fixes bug 1197769

Change-Id: I70aaf6e02fee461fa97dc254db906d9efa173669

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-03 21:39:37.000000000', 'message': "Fix power_state lookup in confirm_resize

Previously the compute manager's confirm_resize method was trying to get
the current power_state of the resized/migrated instance from the
hypervisor layer to account for a case where the user migrated from a
stopped instance and then powered it on via the hypervisor (below
openstack) to test it before confirming the migration.  This doesn't
work in the migrate case but the confirm_resize request is serviced on
the source compute node, and the instance no longer lives there so
_get_power_state results in an InstanceNotFound.  The vm_state would
then be set to ACTIVE even though the instance's power_state is still
SHUTDOWN.

This patch fixes this problem by just getting the instance power_state
from the database since the scenario of powering on the migrated
instance outside of openstack is not supported.

Fixes bug 1197514

Change-Id: If2ea83cd317aa8897b7b6bd6b43a2067e1074e33
"}, {'created': '2013-07-03 21:41:01.000000000', 'message': "Fix power_state lookup in confirm_resize

work in the migrate case because the confirm_resize request is serviced
on the source compute node, and the instance no longer lives there so
_get_power_state results in an InstanceNotFound.  The vm_state would
then be set to ACTIVE even though the instance's power_state is still
SHUTDOWN.

This patch fixes this problem by just getting the instance power_state
from the database since the scenario of powering on the migrated
instance outside of openstack is not supported.

Fixes bug 1197514

Change-Id: If2ea83cd317aa8897b7b6bd6b43a2067e1074e33

commit_message:
Fix power_state lookup in confirm_resize

Previously the compute manager's confirm_resize method was trying to get
the current power_state of the resized/migrated instance from the
hypervisor layer to account for a case where the user migrated from a
stopped instance and then powered it on via the hypervisor (below
openstack) to test it before confirming the migration.  This doesn't
work in the migrate case because the confirm_resize request is serviced
on the source compute node, and the instance no longer lives there so
_get_power_state results in an InstanceNotFound.  The vm_state would
then be set to ACTIVE even though the instance's power_state is still
SHUTDOWN.

This patch fixes this problem by just getting the instance power_state
from the database since the scenario of powering on the migrated
instance outside of openstack is not supported.

Fixes bug 1197514

Change-Id: If2ea83cd317aa8897b7b6bd6b43a2067e1074e33

Yes, I agree that this import standard makes imports less readable. But how often are they read? IMO less often than all code itself. Moreover, full paths let reviewers see the folder structure instead of keeping it in mind. I don't think the reasons given so far really justify the effect this has on readability. I've made a mailing list post here:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-July/011502.html"}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-07-09 12:04:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I agree that requiring absolute imports make the codes less readable.
Horizon imports tends to become TOO TOO long :-(

IMO, it is better to allow relative imports to some extent.
In Horizon codes, most imports are within a same panel
(where "panel" means openstack_dashboard/dashboards/{project,admin}/XXXXX).

My idea is to allow relative imports within a panel only
and to use absolute imports from other panels.

To me, relative imports to parent directories such as
"from ... import instances"  are not easy to understand either.
("." is easy to understand and ".." is still acceptable...)

What do you think?

# I change my score since there is no consensus now. (+1 is technically good)'}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-07-10 09:01:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I like Akihiro's idea of only allowing same-level relative imports. Otherwise indeed it also becomes difficult to read and understand."}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2013-07-15 19:24:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-16 16:57:32.000000000', 'message': "Bug # 1200232 - force_dhcp_release now defaults to True.

Historically it was was False because it requires the dnsmasq binary
'dhcp_release' which was not present in all distributions. Most
content and sample files already recommended setting the value to
True, I have updated the few instances I found where it seemed
applicable to highlight that True is now the default. I did leave one
mention where it is recommended to set False for RHEL 6.2 because this
is still the case.

There is probably a wider discussion needed there about whether
at this point we should recommend >= RHEL 6.3 or even 6.4 for
Grizzly/Havana as it significantly improves the availability of
packages for a number of issues like this).

Change-Id: Ief819e1d3366ee1e1cd42f6bd8b61eaf7c20401d
Fixes: bug 1200232
"}]
commit_message:
Bug # 1200232 - force_dhcp_release now defaults to True.

Historically it was was False because it requires the dnsmasq binary
'dhcp_release' which was not present in all distributions. Most
content and sample files already recommended setting the value to
True, I have updated the few instances I found where it seemed
applicable to highlight that True is now the default. I did leave one
mention where it is recommended to set False for RHEL 6.2 because this
is still the case.

There is probably a wider discussion needed there about whether
at this point we should recommend >= RHEL 6.3 or even 6.4 for
Grizzly/Havana as it significantly improves the availability of
packages for a number of issues like this).

Change-Id: Ief819e1d3366ee1e1cd42f6bd8b61eaf7c20401d
Fixes: bug 1200232

commit_message:
Be sure to check deleted types on quota update.

If a volume-type is deleted, and later a volume
that's assigned that type is deleted the quota
update will fail and result in a trace for
VolumeTypeNotFound exception.

The volume is succesfully deleted, however the
quota information for the volume-type let alone
the other quota items for the volume are not
updated.

Fixes bug: 1200709

Change-Id: Idd687514be9d622df84aad54b1b33ddc6615851b

commit_message:
Change the swift file deletion to use the manifest.

* Adding a _parse_manifest helper to parse the x-object-manifest header
* Delete file using the prefix in the manifest.
* Fix error handling in the delete_backup method.

Fixes Bug: #1194653

Change-Id: I34268f768a5cdb8085607269e2c2cb95974a539d

'}, {'created': '2013-07-12 18:49:15.000000000', 'message': 'Periodic task for offloading shelved instances

Adds a periodic task which removes a shelved instance from a hypervisor
if it has been shelved > CONF.shelved_offload_time seconds.

CONF.shelved_offload_time can also be set to -1 to mean never offload,
and 0 to mean offload immediately when shelved.

Setting a >0 shelved_offload_time means that hypervisor resources will
still be in used until the periodic task offloads them.  So capacity is
not reduced, but unshelving times may be decreased.

Offloading immediately means that capacity becomes available quickly,
but may increase unshelving times if the instance is not volume backed
and its snapshot takes a long time to transfer.

DocImpact
Part of bp shelve-instance

Change-Id: I49ee53709270aa25de76d58666c250537f6a0314

commit_message:
Periodic task for offloading shelved instances

Adds a periodic task which removes a shelved instance from a hypervisor
if it has been shelved > CONF.shelved_offload_time seconds.

CONF.shelved_offload_time can also be set to -1 to mean never offload,
and 0 to mean offload immediately when shelved.

Setting a >0 shelved_offload_time means that hypervisor resources will
still be in used until the periodic task offloads them.  So capacity is
not reduced, but unshelving times may be decreased.

Offloading immediately means that capacity becomes available quickly,
but may increase unshelving times if the instance is not volume backed
and its snapshot takes a long time to transfer.

DocImpact
Part of bp shelve-instance

Change-Id: I49ee53709270aa25de76d58666c250537f6a0314

commit_message:
Use db.flavor_ instead of db.instance_type_

We are removing instance_type as a synonym for a flavor. This fixes that
for the db.ap.

Partially implements bp flavor-instance-type-dedup

Change-Id: Id41b3b86a7af476622c70415080f4982c267a646

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-11 19:32:52.000000000', 'message': 'Add AgregatesManager.get()

utils.find_resource() uses manager.get() as part of converting Resource
names to IDs.  AggregatesManager had get_details() instead of get().

Add AggregatesManager.get(), leaving .get_details() in place for backward
API compatibility.

Bug: 1200341

Change-Id: I7d238bbe43e1760e31f1a9ba783c668246f20844
'}]
commit_message:
Add AgregatesManager.get()

utils.find_resource() uses manager.get() as part of converting Resource
names to IDs.  AggregatesManager had get_details() instead of get().

Add AggregatesManager.get(), leaving .get_details() in place for backward
API compatibility.

Bug: 1200341

Change-Id: I7d238bbe43e1760e31f1a9ba783c668246f20844

[{'created': '2013-07-09 06:33:41.000000000', 'message': "Remove uncessary code related to nova start/stop

'nova start' and 'nova stop' actually send request with 'os-start'
and 'os-stop', instead of 'start' and 'stop'.

Change-Id: I1472e1b648dae8f3b281a113adb60421a00e5a48
"}]
commit_message:
Remove uncessary code related to nova start/stop

'nova start' and 'nova stop' actually send request with 'os-start'
and 'os-stop', instead of 'start' and 'stop'.

Change-Id: I1472e1b648dae8f3b281a113adb60421a00e5a48

commit_message:
Add support for rbd in glance

Add support for Ceph/rbd in glance.
Unit test added to spec.

Add package dependency "python-ceph" accordingly to a patch from
Michael Jeanson <mjeanson@gmail.com>.

Change-Id: I0908cde951994db6aba74d2ce3415126c429a76e

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-16 01:42:21.000000000', 'message': 'Deleting not existing floating ip raises 500

The floatingip api layer code does not catch Neutron exceptions so
we need to raise the correct nova floating ip exception so a 404
is raised instead of a 500.

Fixes bug 1200175

Change-Id: I7b498aaca88693f662e712797a7f9931052ad72e
'}]
commit_message:
Deleting not existing floating ip raises 500

The floatingip api layer code does not catch Neutron exceptions so
we need to raise the correct nova floating ip exception so a 404
is raised instead of a 500.

Fixes bug 1200175

Change-Id: I7b498aaca88693f662e712797a7f9931052ad72e

commit_message:
Move `test_migrations` from Nova.

Added class WalkVersionsMixin with common methods for migration tests
(`_migrate_up()`, `_migrate_down()` and `_walk_versions()`).
Tests added.

blueprint test-migrations

Change-Id: I6689c7a01bba7a146ac402a1fe72768a29c72161

[{'created': '2013-06-29 01:38:12.000000000', 'message': 'Adds zsh completion

Use nova bash-completion to add native zsh completion using built in
parameter expansion.  Nothing spectacular or new, this is mostly so that
zsh users do not need to autoload bashcompinit just to use nova.

Change-Id: I56f62f036e0c85e79197f4c7dfd25abf7eb4110a
Implements: zsh completion
'}]
commit_message:
Adds zsh completion

Use nova bash-completion to add native zsh completion using built in
parameter expansion.  Nothing spectacular or new, this is mostly so that
zsh users do not need to autoload bashcompinit just to use nova.

Change-Id: I56f62f036e0c85e79197f4c7dfd25abf7eb4110a
Implements: zsh completion

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-11 06:42:35.000000000', 'message': 'Do not install mysql if mariadb is installed on openSUSE

mariadb and mysql are conflicting on a package level, but are compatible
for our needs. So if mariadb is already installed, do not try to install
mysql.

Change-Id: I3aa991c1c4691df3e3f4798505668da3ab908998
'}]
commit_message:
Do not install mysql if mariadb is installed on openSUSE

mariadb and mysql are conflicting on a package level, but are compatible
for our needs. So if mariadb is already installed, do not try to install
mysql.

Change-Id: I3aa991c1c4691df3e3f4798505668da3ab908998

Change-Id: I0396f1252c8faafff3e8b4f9a4aeffb930350a8d
"}]
commit_message:
CoraidDriver: Allow volumes in error state to be deleted

This fix will allow the delete call to be successfull if volume
doesn't exists on the SAN.

Fixes bug 1195788

Change-Id: I0396f1252c8faafff3e8b4f9a4aeffb930350a8d

Implement extend volume functionality in Sheepdog

This implements the extend volume functionality for Sheepdog driver.

Change-Id: Id7361e9571742bea210f13ced722829f489e7cb0
Implements: blueprint extend-sheepdog-volume

commit_message:
SUSE doesn't have a separate nfs-utils-lib package

but nfs-utils provides the functionality of nfs-utils-lib

Change-Id: I8c24d7cde1b4a6c4860909e25cf20ad499ac85ce

commit_message:
xenapi: Stub out _add_torrent_url for Vhd tests

This will make the FetchVhdImageTestCasetest case play nicer when
a BitTorrent url plugin is installed and the tests are running with
no virtual environment.

Change-Id: I204f14246938981633989654bd3446ca3230c222

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-09 22:19:26.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid deleting user-provided Neutron ports if VM spawn fails

If the VM boot fails, resources like Neutron ports are destroyed.
This is particularly bad if the failure is transient and a
rescheduling attempt is made. In this case the port no longer exist
and the failure becomes self-inflicted. To avoid this, during the
deletion of VM resources, we look at the requested_networks passed
by the user: if they contain port ids, we skip the destruction.

An optional parameter is added to RPC method deallocate_for_instance.
RPC Network API is bumped to 1.10 to reflect this change, but the
change is backward compatible.

Fixes bug #1195490

Change-Id: Iade232267c58ae2cf3966829e660d3298070a3bf

commit_message:
Avoid deleting user-provided Neutron ports if VM spawn fails

If the VM boot fails, resources like Neutron ports are destroyed.
This is particularly bad if the failure is transient and a
rescheduling attempt is made. In this case the port no longer exist
and the failure becomes self-inflicted. To avoid this, during the
deletion of VM resources, we look at the requested_networks passed
by the user: if they contain port ids, we skip the destruction.

An optional parameter is added to RPC method deallocate_for_instance.
RPC Network API is bumped to 1.10 to reflect this change, but the
change is backward compatible.

Fixes bug #1195490

Change-Id: Iade232267c58ae2cf3966829e660d3298070a3bf

subject: Avoid shadowing Exception 'message' attribute

Looks good. Was it the code in nova/wsgi.py that motivated this change?'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-07-01 17:27:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This has been suggested before and it was rejected.

I don't see the point of this change. PEP 352 has deprecated the message attribute on exceptions since Python 2.6 and it doesn't even exist in Python 3.

http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0352/

The suggested way of formatting exceptions should be str() or unicode() anyway since it matches all of the other types."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-07-04 06:01:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-04 06:02:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-07-04 06:05:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-07-04 06:10:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Johannes - thanks for that, very useful.

The main reason I did this was that I found the attribute shadowing just terribly confusing and surprising. I burned a bunch of time just figuring it out. Using a different name avoids that confusion.

Your point about .message being deprecated actually gives more reason to avoid overloading the 'message' name - we want people to avoid using Exception.message, so also having NovaException.message just makes it harder to keep to a simple "never use .message on exceptions" rule.

I've updated the commit message to point out that .message is deprecated and switched from using Exception.message to using str(e)/unicode(e) on NovaExceptions.

(Patch 1->2 is some changes based on Johannes feedback, 2->3 was a rebase to handle a conflict caused by nova.exception.CouldNotFetchMetrics removal)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-04 06:49:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/35117/3/check/gate-nova-pep8/31362 : SUCCESS in 4m 02s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/35117/3/check/gate-nova-docs/25581/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 3m 13s
- http://logs.openstack.org/35117/3/check/gate-nova-python26/26960 : SUCCESS in 29m 51s
- http://logs.openstack.org/35117/3/check/gate-nova-python27/27067 : SUCCESS in 10m 18s
- http://logs.openstack.org/35117/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/28502 : SUCCESS in 38m 43s
- http://logs.openstack.org/35117/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/28208 : SUCCESS in 42m 52s
- http://logs.openstack.org/35117/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/36405 : SUCCESS in 19m 06s
- http://logs.openstack.org/35117/3/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/14836 : FAILURE in 26m 31s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/35117/3/check/gate-nova-pylint/15752 : SUCCESS in 10m 50s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-07-09 15:42:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Even if we're not supposed to be using message anymore, I like this change because the current shadowing is confusing, and if you don't already know the proper way to represent an exception message it's even more difficult to figure it out.  And I should point out that this is not a hypothetical problem.  I wasted quite a bit of time trying to figure it out on another review.

I don't know what it would take to make that happen, but I suppose I could look into it."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-07-15 21:58:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-01 11:13:27.000000000', 'message': "Avoid shadowing Exception 'message' attribute

The Exception class has a 'message' attribute:

  >>> Exception('foo').message
  'foo'

however, we follow a pattern that results in the attribute being
shadowed by a class attribute:

  >>> class MyException(Exception):
  ...     message = 'Foo %s'
  ...     def __init__(self, bar):
  ...         message = self.message % bar
  ...         super(MyException, self).__init__(message)
  ...
  >>> MyException('bar').message
  'Foo %s'

whereas, we obviously want behaviour like this:

  >>> class MyException(Exception):
  ...     msg_fmt = 'Foo %s'
  ...     def __init__(self, bar):
  ...         message = self.msg_fmt % bar
  ...         super(MyException, self).__init__(message)
  ...
  >>> MyException('bar').message
  'Foo bar'

Avoid this shadowing by using 'msg_fmt' as the name of the class
attribute. Add a test which fails without this fix.

Change-Id: I304f31edec20b1293cf6c8de931415590fde6752
"}, {'created': '2013-07-04 06:01:23.000000000', 'message': "Avoid shadowing Exception 'message' attribute

The Exception class has a 'message' attribute:

  >>> Exception('foo').message
  'foo'

This attribute is deprecated since Python 2.6 and removed in Python 3:

  http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0352/#retracted-ideas

To help porting to Python 3, we should avoid using the .message
attribute at all. However, confusingly, we follow a pattern that results
in the attribute being shadowed by a class attribute:

  >>> class MyException(Exception):
  ...     message = 'Foo %s'
  ...     def __init__(self, bar):
  ...         message = self.message % bar
  ...         super(MyException, self).__init__(message)
  ...
  >>> MyException('bar').message
  'Foo %s'
  >>> str(MyException('bar'))
  'Foo bar'

whereas, we obviously want behaviour like this:

  >>> class MyException(Exception):
  ...     msg_fmt = 'Foo %s'
  ...     def __init__(self, bar):
  ...         message = self.msg_fmt % bar
  ...         super(MyException, self).__init__(message)
  ...
  >>> MyException('bar').message
  'Foo bar'
  >>> str(MyException('bar'))
  'Foo bar'

Avoid this shadowing by using 'msg_fmt' as the name of the class
attribute so it's more obvious where we're actually using the deprecated
.message attribute.

Also add a test which fails without this fix.

Change-Id: I304f31edec20b1293cf6c8de931415590fde6752

commit_message:
Avoid shadowing Exception 'message' attribute

The Exception class has a 'message' attribute:

  >>> Exception('foo').message
  'foo'

This attribute is deprecated since Python 2.6 and removed in Python 3:

  http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0352/#retracted-ideas

To help porting to Python 3, we should avoid using the .message
attribute at all. However, confusingly, we follow a pattern that results
in the attribute being shadowed by a class attribute:

  >>> class MyException(Exception):
  ...     message = 'Foo %s'
  ...     def __init__(self, bar):
  ...         message = self.message % bar
  ...         super(MyException, self).__init__(message)
  ...
  >>> MyException('bar').message
  'Foo %s'
  >>> str(MyException('bar'))
  'Foo bar'

whereas, we obviously want behaviour like this:

  >>> class MyException(Exception):
  ...     msg_fmt = 'Foo %s'
  ...     def __init__(self, bar):
  ...         message = self.msg_fmt % bar
  ...         super(MyException, self).__init__(message)
  ...
  >>> MyException('bar').message
  'Foo bar'
  >>> str(MyException('bar'))
  'Foo bar'

Avoid this shadowing by using 'msg_fmt' as the name of the class
attribute so it's more obvious where we're actually using the deprecated
.message attribute.

Also add a test which fails without this fix.

Change-Id: I304f31edec20b1293cf6c8de931415590fde6752

commit_message:
Add API-v3 merged core API into core API list

This completes core API list, so if one of those could not be loaded
an exception will be raised.

The changes on the tests were necessary to avoid whitelist or blacklist all the
core API or get an exception cause one of them wasn't loadi
Also to fix a bug in the tests that override the black or white lists options
and it wasn't in list format causing, for instance, that ips API match with
os-fixed-ips.

Related to bp nova-v3-api

Change-Id: I6e0c6eaa38863495bcabf2e6ce082589becdfe82

I'm not going to -1, but should the checks for valid method be in the @replication decorator?"}, {'account_id': 1531, 'date': '2013-05-29 08:24:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-06-10 20:09:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I was confused by the diff and creiht's comment; but I see now you can't raise the AttributeError from inside the body of the inline def of wrapped because the trap for MethodNotAllowed happens before the method is actually called.  

I'm torn on this patch though.

I think using the decorator to "tag" replication methods makes more sense than defining replication methods by name in the __init__; but I'm worried that the @public decorator and AttributeError pattern is not the ideal style to copy and extend. 

1) I'm confused why public (which the new replication decorator is presumably based on) bothers to define the wrapped method at all?  Why not just set the attribute and return f unmolested?

2) I think the explicit "raise AttributeError" right above "except AttributeError" highlights a bloated exception based goto tree.

3) Having to update the method appropriation in all three backend servers highlights the fact that all these Controller's __call__ methods need to be DRY'd out.

I'm +1 because I like tagging replicate methods with a decorator.  But I don't wanna +2 because I think we need to at least add a comment acknowledging the fact that we're duplicating an existing hard-to-extend model for restricting HTTP verbs rather than fixing it.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-06-13 21:36:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1531, 'date': '2013-06-16 12:03:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

As noted by @Chuck and @Peter is better to move the check logic into the @replication decorator."}, {'account_id': 6529, 'date': '2013-06-19 09:29:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

In Suggestion which you said is interesting but there are some problem. There are three type of servers:
* Replication (option replication_server is True)
* Not replication (option replication_server is False)
* Common (option replication_server is None)
1. On common server ALL function should be possible to start.
2. On replication server ONLY function WITH decorator should be possible to start.
3. On not replication server ONLY function WITHOUT decorator should be possible to start.
So if we want to move checking possibility of starting function from server.py to decorator, then we should add decorators to all function of Controllers class.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-06-26 17:50:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I'm pretty sure Vald's right here.

If we want to rely on the decorator to return 405 for NON replication methods when you're running as a replication-only server then we have to decorate every public controller method with that logic.

As such, I think the whole mess belongs in @public

But I still think we'll want an @replication tag that is just a pass-through attr add; so this is still an incremental improvement IMHO."}, {'account_id': 1531, 'date': '2013-06-28 09:56:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Move replication allow method to decorators

Remove logic of allowed methods list from object, container and account
servers. Instead of it add replicator decorator to utils and use new
decorator for REPLICATE methods in object/account/container servers.
This decorator mark method as special for usfor use only by the
replication.

If the option replication_server is not used, then this mechanism is not
enabled. If the replicaton_server option is set (not None) then the
respective server is a replicator (option value is True) and should use
ONLY the methods marked for replication server using the decorator, or
it is a normal server type and should NOT use methods marked for the
replication server.

Change-Id: I1041b31413cd0c39000317cc57a8c27816e1dfe8

'}, {'account_id': 4912, 'date': '2013-05-30 01:08:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

@Russell

I think auto-delete off makes sense in our environment because we have so many one instance compute nodes that are long lived. I'm not sure it makes sense for everyone though. I worry about changing behavior also, at least for rabbit there were some helper scripts that go through and delete queues with no bindings. I don't think anything like that exists for qpid. I think having a config option with the default how it has always been is great. A good step would be to get some documentation up about how operations changes when auto-delete is off. Ie. Turn this on and you need to clean up after yourselves, etc. Many deployments will never even think about it because they will have lots more instances per compute node, thus less chance of ever getting auto-deleted.

@Paul

I'm with Doug on the generic AMQP config options also. Make sure and leave rabbit_durable_queues as a "deprecated" config option so we don't break anyone. When we get to the point that Russell talks about we can break it out again if it makes sense. Just my $.02'}, {'account_id': 4912, 'date': '2013-05-30 14:55:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Now that I've slept on this I retract my hesitation about making the default False for auto-delete. I'm going to leave the minus one in favor of the amqp prefix on the option name."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-30 18:18:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

commit_message:
Add config for amqp durable/auto_delete queues

This patch makes two new config options (amqp_durable_queues and
amqp_auto_delete) that enable durable and auto delete queues in amqp.

Fixes: bug #1033915
DocImpact
Change-Id: I56e5c92f1ed8ac2d429a306f3f38a963f0138c6c

commit_message:
Fix bug 1197651 account-reaper warns if not making progress

Introduce reap_warn after config variable to determine message timing
patchset 2: diane fleming - editorial changes and spellcheck of file

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-16 13:15:43.000000000', 'message': 'Fix malformed format string.

Also change dict() to {} which is meant to be more efficient:

http://doughellmann.com/2012/11/the-performance-impact-of-using-dict-instead-of-in-cpython-2-7-2.html

This is required for blueprint ec2-error-codes.

Change-Id: Ie32fb43a63ce66c040b5571b13287937bd2df532
'}]
commit_message:
Fix malformed format string.

Also change dict() to {} which is meant to be more efficient:

http://doughellmann.com/2012/11/the-performance-impact-of-using-dict-instead-of-in-cpython-2-7-2.html

This is required for blueprint ec2-error-codes.

Change-Id: Ie32fb43a63ce66c040b5571b13287937bd2df532

subject: Fix unit tests to properly marked deleted files
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 330, 'name': 'John Dickinson', 'email': 'me@not.mn', 'username': 'notmyname'}, {'_account_id': 597, 'name': 'Pete Zaitcev', 'email': 'zaitcev@kotori.zaitcev.us', 'username': 'zaitcev'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2622, 'name': 'Samuel Merritt', 'email': 'sam@swiftstack.com', 'username': 'torgomatic'}, {'_account_id': 6198, 'name': 'Peter Portante', 'email': 'peter.a.portante@gmail.com', 'username': 'peter-a-portante'}, {'_account_id': 7223, 'name': 'Ayal Baron', 'email': 'abaron@redhat.com'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-07-01 21:54:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-07-01 21:56:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Seems sane.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2013-07-01 22:31:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think the commit message does not quite correspond to the problem we're fixing. The problem is that the DiskWriter.put does not officially provide the "extension". It is an implementation detail (DiskFile.put_metadata turns into DiskWriter.put with an extension, but it's hidden from the object server, in theory). So, tests should test the official interface, and the official interface is sufficient, which the small patch proves.

If DiskFile throws metadata into .ts is not very relevant. In fact it's probably a harmless bug in DiskFile. I suggest to drop that sentence from the changelog, because I found it misleading wrt. the intent of the patch.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-01 22:47:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

commit_message:
Fix unit tests to properly marked deleted files

The unit tests were playing fast and loose with the tombstone marker,
where the test framework was setting up a DiskFile object which had
its data written to the .ts file, not the .data file. This behavior
did not reflect how the interfaces to DiskFile were supposed to
work.

Change-Id: Idd6e8882e062ba2e13489f14189223ab4158677c
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
xenapi - rename quantum to neutron

Some changes were missing from the previous rename patch, so it broke
XenServer support. This patch contains the missing adjustments.

related to blueprint remove-use-of-quantum

Change-Id: I1ee5cc38d555bd5c26edf00a456ec71919604d79

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-25 15:23:04.000000000', 'message': "Pluggable Token Provider (Part 2)

This patch implemented V2 token provider, which is the second part of
blueprint pluggable-token-format.

Abstract token provider backend to make token provider pluggable. It enables
deployers to customize token management to add their own capabilities.
Token provider is responsible for issuing, checking, validating, and
revoking tokens. Note the distinction between token 'driver' and 'provider'.
Token 'driver' simply provides token CRUD. It does not issue or interpret
tokens.

Token provider is specified by the 'provider' property in the '[token]'
section of the Keystone configuration file.

Note: This is one of the redos of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29021
as it was too big and we need to submit the review in smaller chunks.

Change-Id: Ic418ec433bd9e3f2f70fa31c90e570e32c1ca687

commit_message:
Implements Pluggable V2 Token Provider

This patch implemented V2 token provider.

Abstract token provider backend to make token provider pluggable. It enables
deployers to customize token management to add their own capabilities.
Token provider is responsible for issuing, checking, validating, and
revoking tokens. Note the distinction between token 'driver' and 'provider'.
Token 'driver' simply provides token CRUD. It does not issue or interpret
tokens.

Token provider is specified by the 'provider' property in the '[token]'
section of the Keystone configuration file.

Change-Id: Ic418ec433bd9e3f2f70fa31c90e570e32c1ca687

commit_message:
Enable policy control over external_gateway_info sub-attributes

Part 2 of blueprint l3-ext-gw-modes

This patch extends the logic for building policy rule matches in order to
include sub-attributes as well. This logic will be leveraged by the
ext-gw-mode api extension.

Change-Id: I7f46a395597b71bb1c5110aa4e792a04a5010d4c

[{'created': '2013-07-03 14:50:09.000000000', 'message': 'Fix EC2 DescribeTags filter

as the filter key_name for describe_tags.

Fix bug 1197294

Change-Id: Id7deb28803b0c93c5077306be9afa5ddf1e76a32
'}, {'created': '2013-07-16 12:59:30.000000000', 'message': 'Fix EC2 DescribeTags filter

Support resource-id and resource-type as the filter key_name for
describe_tags.

Fix bug 1197294

Change-Id: Id7deb28803b0c93c5077306be9afa5ddf1e76a32
'}]
commit_message:
Fix EC2 DescribeTags filter

Support resource-id and resource-type as the filter key_name for
describe_tags.

Fix bug 1197294

Change-Id: Id7deb28803b0c93c5077306be9afa5ddf1e76a32

commit_message:
Add support for globbing in data files

Similar to the work in the packages argument, allow the specification
of a directory to recursively include as part of the install.

Change-Id: Ife0414af468e7fcd4fc419eafc3e19e29efcfc7b

commit_message:
xenapi: Add disk config value to xenstore.

To be able to access the value of disk_config from inside the VM,
added the value to xenstore.

Implements blueprint add-disk-config-to-xenstore
Change-Id: I21170252400ffc73f386dbd19aaa9f7a7613bd56

commit_message:
xenapi:populating hypervisor version in host state

This will be used in the scheduler to compare it to the image
properties.
Pulled out conversion of version string into integer to utils.
Partially implements blueprint xen-support-for-hypervisor-versions

Change-Id: Ib2eb91f6f18af6d39f9381daeff7ba9a24b4785a

commit_message:
removed unused variable 'registry_port'

The unused variable 'registry_port' has been removed from function

'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-07-13 21:16:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Patch Set 13 addresses Yong's comment

I believe server side performance will be also increased,
because message processing will be merged in agent side, and it decreases 
db request.

For example, when we assign 10 floating ips in the router in the 5 sec.
previous impl issues 10 db request, and it takes 5min in agent side (30 sec per 1 request).
Current implementations issues two db request, and it takes 1min to process it in agent side."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-07-13 21:16:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-13 21:39:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-12 19:52:37.000000000', 'message': "Fix race confition in l3-agent and improve performance

When I boot 10 vm, and assign 10 floatings ips,
only about half of it will be configured in 60 sec.
There is some timing issue and perfomances issues.

- Current l3-agent will not execute rpc
call by order which has been called. This will lose
some configrations

- iptables apply is a heavy operation.
But it is used in several places.

- Sometimes RPC stucks.
so let's say we got 10 floating ip update rpc request
for a server during processsing routers.
In this case, it is enough to process the last call.
However current implementation will process all requests.
This will delayed 10th floating ip configrations.

- Each router run is executed in batch way.

In this patch, I took very simple and safe strategy.

- Any update rpc call will simply set fullsync=true
- rpcloop will check the fullsync for each sec, then
execute fullsync
- use iptables_manager.defer_apply_on
- spawn for each router operation

This patch makes the 10 floating ips test works.

This patch will increases requests for servers,
however this could be future work.

I expect this patch fixes bug 1194026.
fixes 1200749

Change-Id: I0978d1c38ac5c38c4548e5b1877857bb5cac3b81

"}, {'created': '2013-07-12 22:15:12.000000000', 'message': "Fix race condition in l3-agent and improve performance

When we boot 10 vms, and assign 10 floatings ips,
only about half of it will be configured in 60 sec.
There are some timing issue and perfomances issues.

- Current l3-agent will not execute rpc
Re-ordering of rpc message execution will lose
some configuration.

- iptables apply is a heavy operation.
But it is used in several places.

- Sometimes RPC will temporarily block for unexpectedly long periods
so let's say we got 10 floating ip update rpc request
for a server during processsing routers.
In this case, it is enough to process the last call.
However current implementation will process all requests.
This will delayed 10th floating ip configurations.

- Each router run is executed in batch way.

In this patch, we took very simple and safe strategy.

- Any update rpc call will simply set fullsync=true
- rpcloop will check the fullsync for each sec, then
execute fullsync
- use iptables_manager.defer_apply_on
- spawn for each router operation

This patch makes the 10 floating ips test works.

This patch will increases requests for servers,
however this could be future work.

Fixes bug 1194026.
Fixes bug 1200749

Change-Id: I0978d1c38ac5c38c4548e5b1877857bb5cac3b81

"}, {'created': '2013-07-15 18:56:47.000000000', 'message': "Fix race condition in l3-agent and improve performance

When we boot 10 vms, and assign 10 floatings ips,
only about half of it will be configured in 60 sec.
There are some timing issue and perfomances issues.

- Current l3-agent will not execute rpc
Re-ordering of rpc message execution will lose
some configuration.

- Iptables apply is a heavy operation.
But it is used in several places.

- Sometimes RPC will temporarily block for unexpectedly long periods
so let's say we got 10 floating ip update rpc request
for a server during processsing routers.
In this case, it is enough to process the last call.
However current implementation will process all requests.
This will delayed 10th floating ip configurations.

- Each router run is executed in batch way.

In this patch, we took very simple and safe strategy.

- Any update rpc call will simply set fullsync=true
- rpcloop will check the fullsync for each sec, then
execute fullsync
- use iptables_manager.defer_apply_on
- spawn for each router operation

- Remove sync data from server side notification.
This changes needs a fix for transaction.

This patch makes the 10 floating ips test works.

This patch will increases requests for servers,
however this could be future work.

Fixes bug 1194026
Fixes bug 1200749

Change-Id: I0978d1c38ac5c38c4548e5b1877857bb5cac3b81

"}, {'created': '2013-07-16 00:27:19.000000000', 'message': 'Improve l3-agent performance and prevent races in it.

Fixes bug 1194026
Fixes bug 1200749

Introduce a looping call for performing synchronization with
neutron server.
The sync will be performed only if router changes are notified
via rpc. Only affected routers will be synchronized.

Changes will be implemented by the l3 agent spawning a
distinct greenthread for each router - iptables will
be executed only once using iptables_manager.defer_apply_on.

This patch will prevent the occurence of the following issues:
- Out-of-order rpc message processing
- Long processing time for router changes due to serial execution
- Occasional and expected RPC blocks for long periods
- Unnecessary processing of multiple requests

Change-Id: I0978d1c38ac5c38c4548e5b1877857bb5cac3b81

commit_message:
Improve l3-agent performance and prevent races in it.

Fixes bug 1194026
Fixes bug 1200749

Introduce a looping call for performing synchronization with
neutron server.
The sync will be performed only if router changes are notified
via rpc. Only affected routers will be synchronized.

Changes will be implemented by the l3 agent spawning a
distinct greenthread for each router - iptables will
be executed only once using iptables_manager.defer_apply_on.

This patch will prevent the occurence of the following issues:
- Out-of-order rpc message processing
- Long processing time for router changes due to serial execution
- Occasional and expected RPC blocks for long periods
- Unnecessary processing of multiple requests

Change-Id: I0978d1c38ac5c38c4548e5b1877857bb5cac3b81

commit_message:
index checksum image property

checksum image property will be indexed so that users can search for an
image by specifying the checksum

Change-Id: I31543afed31512f8f5f613640012bc7c1d7ea993
Implements: blueprint index-using-checksum-image-property

commit_message:
Move dnsdomain_* tests in test_db_api to own test case.

There is dnsdomain_* tests in old mixed DbApiTestCase.
This patch moves them to its own test case DnsdomainTestCase.

Missing test_dnsdomain_unregister added.

blueprint db-api-tests

Change-Id: I9c11ff723d3001499ada54786d09ff397e8fb6e2

commit_message:
Remove duplicated key_pair* tests from test_db_api.

There is some key_pair* tests in old DbApiTestCase
which are duplicated in new KeyPairTestCase.
This patch simply remove them.

commit_message:
Add missing tests for db.api.instance_* methods

Add missing and fixed existing tests.

Mostly replaced assertEqual(2, len(result)) by _assertEqualListOfInstances
and some other minor nits.

blueprint db-api-tests

Change-Id: Ia81dc1d75cbceb3ab882a02a66b3d9ce292816c1

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-06-27 20:34:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-06-27 20:48:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

So does the config file override the Cell model entirely?  It's a little strange to support both of them.

I wonder if it'd be good enough to simply create a one-off script to generate the cell config file from the DB table?  The goal would be to only support a single method of config.  Let me know what you think.

I have a slight preference for INI style files as they are easier to hand edit, but JSON is OK also.

Some comments inline also.  Thanks :)"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-06-27 21:07:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: (2 inline comments)

Yeah, the config file overrides the Cell model entirely.  I had considered whether a one-off script to generate the cell config file from the DB table would make sense, but the problem with that approach is that there is no upgrade path that seems compatible with continuous integration; you would essentially have to flag-day your entire nova installation to move it from one to the other.  With this approach, you can continue using the deprecated in-db approach, generate the cells configuration file (probably using nova-manage—not yet written), then switch over to using that.

I also personally dislike phased approaches like this, but when you're working with a large distributed system where each component ends up getting upgraded separately, it really is virtually the only way to go for some of the more invasive changes…"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-27 21:31:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-07-12 22:37:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

The __new__ usage is pretty slick.  Pythonic object factory!

Do you want to put an example config file somewhere?  Perhaps in etc/nova?

On a random side note, I don't get the point of configuring cells through the API.  Unless I'm missing something obvious, it only works if you put an API server in every cell.  Each cell requires configuration for its parent and child before they can communicate with one another and obviously you have a chicken and egg problem if you attempt to configure your cells through RPC. :)"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-07-12 22:48:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: (3 inline comments)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-25 21:02:08.000000000', 'message': "*WIP* Load cell data from a configuration file

Cells currently keeps all inter-cell communication data, including
usernames and passwords, in the database.  This is undesirable and
unnecessary, since cells data isn't updated very frequently.  This
change allows cells data to be drawn from a JSON file specified via
a new [cells]cells_config option.  When specified, the database is
no longer consulted when reloading cells data.

Implements blueprint eliminate-clear-passwords-from-cells-table.

TODO:

* Update the cells extension to turn off (return 403?) the create,
  delete, and update operations
* Update the cells extension to call to the cells manager for get
  and list operations, allowing the configuration file to only
  need to be present on the cell manager node(s)
* Update the test suite to test the newly-added code and verify
  behavior when cells_config is provided

Change-Id: I7046ce55a0a294293c1b1a5fb0f092aeb891ee01

"}, {'created': '2013-06-27 20:34:24.000000000', 'message': "Load cell data from a configuration file

**WIP**

Cells currently keeps all inter-cell communication data, including
usernames and passwords, in the database.  This is undesirable and
unnecessary, since cells data isn't updated very frequently.  This
change allows cells data to be drawn from a JSON file specified via
a new [cells]cells_config option.  When specified, the database is
no longer consulted when reloading cells data.

Implements blueprint eliminate-clear-passwords-from-cells-table.

DocImpact: Cells may now optionally be configured through a JSON-
formatted file.  The file will need the columns present in the Cell
model (excluding common database fields and the 'id' column).  The
queue connection information must be specified through a
'transport_url' field, instead of 'username', 'password', etc.  The
transport_url has the following form:

    rabbit://<username>:<password>@<hostname>:<port>/<virtual_host>

The scheme may be either 'rabbit' (shown above) or 'qpid'.

TODO:

* Update the test suite to test the newly-added code and verify
  behavior when cells_config is provided

Change-Id: I7046ce55a0a294293c1b1a5fb0f092aeb891ee01

'transport_url' field, instead of 'username', 'password', etc.  The
transport_url has the following form:

    rabbit://<username>:<password>@<hostname>:<port>/<virtual_host>

The scheme may be either 'rabbit' (shown above) or 'qpid'.

Change-Id: I7046ce55a0a294293c1b1a5fb0f092aeb891ee01

commit_message:
Load cell data from a configuration file

Cells currently keeps all inter-cell communication data, including
usernames and passwords, in the database.  This is undesirable and
unnecessary, since cells data isn't updated very frequently.  This
change allows cells data to be drawn from a JSON file specified via
a new [cells]cells_config option.  When specified, the database is
no longer consulted when reloading cells data.

Implements blueprint eliminate-clear-passwords-from-cells-table.

DocImpact: Cells may now optionally be configured through a JSON-
formatted file.  The file will need the columns present in the Cell
model (excluding common database fields and the 'id' column).  The
queue connection information must be specified through a
'transport_url' field, instead of 'username', 'password', etc.  The
transport_url has the following form:

    rabbit://<username>:<password>@<hostname>:<port>/<virtual_host>

The scheme may be either 'rabbit' (shown above) or 'qpid'.

Change-Id: I7046ce55a0a294293c1b1a5fb0f092aeb891ee01

commit_message:
Add version override support from nova.

Nova has a great feature that allows distro packagers to override
version strings by putting config files in known locations. We should
support this in our version processing code, because it's quite handy.

Change-Id: Ibb80649b45ecab90f982138cb07d2e5a8b7ac6d9

commit_message:
Defer to pip for requirements processing

pip knows what it's doing, we should stop doing its job for it.
Additionally, we should not inject version numbers into the
install_requires itself, as upstream pip tells us this is bad form.
install_requires should list the requirement itself, requirements.txt
should indicate the version that should be installed.

Change-Id: I3b6708444ec8b3d37271c0c8df91fee2cd593088

SOURCES.txt file when we need to. That is:

 - If there is no SOURCES.txt, make one
 - If we have run the sdist command, make one

Otherwise, leave well enough alone.

Also, skip doing any git processing if SKIP_GIT_FILES is specified.

commit_message:
Replace setuptools_git with a smarter approach.

Implement a local egg_info command that only re-generates the
SOURCES.txt file when we need to. That is:

 - If there is no SOURCES.txt, make one
 - If we have run the sdist command, make one

Otherwise, leave well enough alone.

Also, skip doing any git processing if SKIP_GIT_FILES is specified.

This should mean that consumers of our tarballs should not get screwed
by the need to inject git processing into the sdist.

Change-Id: I163b1c153d030e79b120600a2890edeb49e1fa90

[{'created': '2013-07-12 07:05:43.000000000', 'message': 'Merge feature/merged2to1 into master

commit_message:
Merge feature/merged2to1 into master

Upstream d2to1 has been rather unresponsive, and doing what we need
in this case is really easier without the extra complexity.

Change-Id: Ibd16944e76ad8398b57b6ddcbcd150cd462add3e

This should probably me marked as a work in progress until the client libs land in oslo.'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-15 17:26:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

mmh, the idea would be to let it land in marconiclient/common (instead of openstack/common) in order to test the lib, examine the API and use this client as a "test environment" for this lib.

Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-05-15 18:38:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-15 18:53:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Flavio, that does make some sense, if this is a new client. I expect we'll see a fair amount of change to the APIs, though, so I thought it might be better to let a first draft land in oslo. It's up to you all, though, I was just making a suggestion. :-)"}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-05-15 19:02:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think that it's useful to put the library to marconiclient as it were in oslo already (so, use marconiclient.openstack.common.apiclient). It makes easy to develop the library in oslo, then run `python update.py` for each client package and run unit test in it. That's how I have written all my commits to clients.

I would like to emphasize that running unit tests in python*client packages and executing their command-line utilities will help discovering errors in apiclient, show its convenience (or inconvenience :) ), and will help to decide whether it's ready to be used in python*clients. That's why I'm so optimistic about apiclient's future.

Could we accept my patch in some form to upstream and continue improving it in further commits? I think we can even accept apiclient to oslo (while python*clients will be unchanged). Even more, I think that my own example shows that updating other packages (to make them use apiclient) can be performed in reasonable time.

The next steps would be adding uncompressed SSL (it's important for glanceclient) and switching to stevedore in auth_plugins."}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-05-15 19:27:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-15 19:28:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/29255/2/check/gate-python-marconiclient-pep8/7 : SUCCESS in 43s

- http://logs.openstack.org/29255/2/check/gate-python-marconiclient-python27/7 : SUCCESS in 45s
'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-15 20:09:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hey Alessio,

We'll have a meeting tomorrow and we're planning to discuss the client stuff. It would be really nice to have you in the meeting so we can talk about how we're planning to implement this, improve it and make sure it gets ready to be moved to oslo.

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-May/009072.html

Feel free to drop me an email (or look for me on IRC flaper87) if you need anything."}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-05-18 10:20:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-18 10:21:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-06-15 03:19:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

Thank you!'}, {'account_id': 6427, 'date': '2013-06-19 15:24:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

General feedback:

* BaseManager is understandably designed for APIs that aren't as strict about following the REST architectural style as is Marconi. You can see this in the way URIs are built; the client should not be constructing URIs based on out-of-band schemas. I suppose marconiclient can use CrudManager (which should actually be named CRUDManager btw per PEP-8), and just pass pre-built hrefs returned from the API as "base_url" with no keyword args, but it seems like we could come up with a cleaner solution here.
* Could stevedore be used to faciliate the Extension class?
* Several modules could be reduced in size (number of lines of code) by following DRY principles.
* Mixed use of " and ' for quoting string literals. Several other violations of marconi's HACKING guide (which I would like to copy to this project as well).

All of these could be done in subsequent patches (bp's) if you like.'}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-06-20 18:58:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-20 18:59:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Doesn't seem to work
