(2 inline comments)

I'm reviewing this more thoroughly, since I've noticed there's too much magic going on. I've posted some initial comments with this review. I expect to add more soon."}, {'account_id': 6944, 'date': '2013-07-12 21:15:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(12 inline comments)

I think there's too much being submitted as a single patch set. I've tried to be thorough in my review, and a lot of work has gone into this. Most of my concerns can be categorized as follows:

1. Python 3 compatibility - we should strive to move towards full Py3k compliance with each new commit to Openstack. This introduces a few steps backwards.

2. There seems to be a lot of "magic" going on. I admit I haven't worked in the openstack ways for very long, so I'm not familiar with the conventions of Resources, Managers, and Clients and the data and methods that are usually clumped with each.

I understand the desire to create a common openstack client library. I disagree with it existing within any one project, even as a test bed.

Why not create a separate project for this? Then, other openstack clients can list it as an install-time dependency. To help it grow, and as client developers find recurring patterns and perform refactorings, they can contribute to the openstack-client-common repo.

Thanks for working on this, but I cannot recommend this to be merged.'}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-07-15 08:12:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25: (14 inline comments)

Thank you for the interest to my code, Alejandro!'}, {'account_id': 6944, 'date': '2013-07-15 17:11:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 25: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(9 inline comments)

After reviewing Alessio's comments, there's still room for improvement, but this is reasonable to merge at this time.

However, as Marconi client developers, we must use only what we need, and with absolute imports. It is my understanding that these common libraries will become an install-time dependency, so it's reasonable to treat them as if they weren't a part of this code base.

There's room for improvement, but I'm satisfied that we can work with this as is."}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-07-15 17:24:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25:

Thank you very much, Alejandro!'}, {'account_id': 7044, 'date': '2013-07-16 02:21:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-07-16 07:51:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 25: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

+2'd although it is not release ready.

I beg everyone to take a look at this pad[0] for comments and ideas about the client and this library. I'll also create some bugs (and cards) to track things that should be changed, please help me creating those.

Thanks Alessio for your hard work and patience and to everyone for reviewing this patch."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-07-16 07:51:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25:

[0] https://etherpad.openstack.org/apiclient-marconi

:D'}, {'account_id': 6427, 'date': '2013-07-16 15:54:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Approving with the assumption that the code will continue to be cleaned up and improved in future patches per:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/apiclient-marconi'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-16 15:54:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25: No score

commit_message:
Add apiclient library

This library can be used in novaclient, keystoneclient,
glanceclient, and other client projects. The library
contains common code and uses python-requests for
HTTP communication.

Features:
* reissue authentication request for expired tokens;
* pluggable authentication;
* rich exceptions hierarchy;
* utils for building CLI tools.

Partially implements: blueprint common-client-library

Change-Id: I82df865d52f32ce47dde6a09a84d3d917fd77918

make publisher procedure call configurable

allow configurable publisher to cast to procedure other than
record_metering_data

new conclusion from talk is uncapping all the clients, with the exception of neutron client, because they need to make some incompatible changes on their next major release.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2013-07-15 11:14:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hey Kung Huang,

I know you sent this patch first and I also don't like when someone step on my toes and send another patch after mine fixing the same problem. But, in this case, there's another patch in the review list (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/36992/) fixing the same problem which seems to be more complete and is not failing on the gate, so I'm just -1 yours because I'm thinking about the health of the project itself here and not as a personal thing. Hope you understand."}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-07-15 12:41:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

You're so kind Lucas, but Dirk is .....

But another thing is Dirk didn't find what Sean Dauge said. Removing all upper bound is an old way. Now quantum client is an exception because of some incompatible changes.

Here is his patch on nova (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/36907/), I think keep upper bound of quantum client is a good idea.

Gate is another issue, and they're working on this. I don't know details but I guess there's a sequence of these patches, we have to merge it one by one and passed by gate."}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-07-15 12:42:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck  bug #1200214'}, {'account_id': 5805, 'date': '2013-07-15 14:16:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Kun,
Dirk's Ironic patch for the same bug also updates test-requirements.txt. As long as we are making this changes to the requirements files we should also update the python-quantum to python-neutronclient."}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-07-15 16:04:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-15 16:22:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
update requires to prevent version cap

OpenStack clients. None of these should have an upper bound
as that has implications for testing in the gate. An exception
is currently being made for neutron client because of the need
for an incompatible change in their next release.
https://github.com/openstack/requirements

fixes bug #1200214

Change-Id: I6cc851554e2dcc620bfeb45dc63c9d80d09e9586

[{'created': '2013-07-02 12:07:19.000000000', 'message': 'Fix issue with pip installing oslo.config-1.2.0

Fixes bug #1194807

Firstly, we update the oslo.config dep to 1.2.0a3 because of the issue
with namespace packages (bug #1194742).

But the main issue here is that when we previously depended on 1.2.0a3
we found that if you did:

  $> pip install -r nova/requirements.txt

then you end up with the oslo.config 1.1.1 code installed. This is
because oslo.config>=1.1.0 gets pulled in as a transitive dep and pip
gets confused.

See I977700d73342e81ee962019b76238d2cb2b1fff4

You can reproduce with e.g.

  $> pip install \
       http://.../oslo.config-1.2.0a3.tar.gz#egg=oslo.config-1.2.0a3 \
       python-keystoneclient
  $> pip freeze | grep oslo.config
  oslo.config-1.2.0a3
  $> python -c 'from oslo.config.cfg import DeprecatedOpt'
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  ImportError: cannot import name DeprecatedOpt

This is because of a bug with pip where it sees oslo.config-1.2.0a3 and
oslo.config as two unrelated things. It should strip the version part of
the egg= fragment before using it as a package name, but it doesn't.

However, we can simply use the -f/--find-links pip option in our
requirements.txt to add the tarball URL to the list of URLs considered
and also add the oslo.config>=1.2.0a3 dependency:

  $> pip install \
       -f http://.../oslo.config-1.2.0a3.tar.gz#egg=oslo.config-1.2.0a3 \
       'oslo.config>=1.2.0a3' \
       python-keystoneclient
  $> pip freeze | grep oslo.config
  oslo.config-1.2.0a3
  $> python -c 'from oslo.config.cfg import DeprecatedOpt'

This is actually exactly the semantics we want and we go to great
lengths in pbr to get these semantics while using a single tarball URL.
The only downside to this --find-links strategy is that we gain an extra
line in our requirements.txt ... but it does work around the pip bug.

Change-Id: I6f3eb5fd2c75615d9a1cae172aed859b36b27d4c

commit_message:
Fix issue with pip installing oslo.config-1.2.0

Fixes bug #1194807

Firstly, we update the oslo.config dep to 1.2.0a3 because of the issue
with namespace packages (bug #1194742).

But the main issue here is that when we previously depended on 1.2.0a3
we found that if you did:

  $> pip install -r nova/requirements.txt

then you end up with the oslo.config 1.1.1 code installed. This is
because oslo.config>=1.1.0 gets pulled in as a transitive dep and pip
gets confused.

See I977700d73342e81ee962019b76238d2cb2b1fff4

You can reproduce with e.g.

  $> pip install \
       http://.../oslo.config-1.2.0a3.tar.gz#egg=oslo.config-1.2.0a3 \
       python-keystoneclient
  $> pip freeze | grep oslo.config
  oslo.config-1.2.0a3
  $> python -c 'from oslo.config.cfg import DeprecatedOpt'
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  ImportError: cannot import name DeprecatedOpt

This is because of a bug with pip where it sees oslo.config-1.2.0a3 and
oslo.config as two unrelated things. It should strip the version part of
the egg= fragment before using it as a package name, but it doesn't.

However, we can simply use the -f/--find-links pip option in our
requirements.txt to add the tarball URL to the list of URLs considered
and also add the oslo.config>=1.2.0a3 dependency:

  $> pip install \
       -f http://.../oslo.config-1.2.0a3.tar.gz#egg=oslo.config-1.2.0a3 \
       'oslo.config>=1.2.0a3' \
       python-keystoneclient
  $> pip freeze | grep oslo.config
  oslo.config-1.2.0a3
  $> python -c 'from oslo.config.cfg import DeprecatedOpt'

This is actually exactly the semantics we want and we go to great
lengths in pbr to get these semantics while using a single tarball URL.
The only downside to this --find-links strategy is that we gain an extra
line in our requirements.txt ... but it does work around the pip bug.

Change-Id: I6f3eb5fd2c75615d9a1cae172aed859b36b27d4c

commit_message:
Implement chassis api actions

Partially implements blueprint chassis-api-actions:
* adds 'description' field to chassis
* api to retrieve list of chassis
* api to retrieve details of a single chassis
* api to create/update/delete a chassis

Change-Id: I02bee4e10dcee233209e57025c18e5ae5cea86f8

Marking as -1 because I want Flavio to take a look, but I'll revisit if he doesn't get around to it"}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-07-11 12:01:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

Hey, Sorry it took me so long to get to this patch.

I added a few comments in-line. 

WRT making enforcer a keyword, I think it is better to always pass it through. Checks should be called using the enforcer.enforce which pass itself to the Check. I discourage users from calling checks directly without passing through the enforcer.

Also, could you please add more tests for other Checks?

Thanks for working on this."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-07-11 12:01:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Fix missing argument bug in oslo common policy

Some checks in policy module missing a argument, this
patch fixed it by adding the necessary argument.

Fixed bug #1194354

Change-Id: I41338675842be517146062d11012462c5c90d6e5

commit_message:
Added alembic migrations

Added alembic dependency to requirements
Created alembic config files

To create alembic migration:
$ cd ./ceilometer/storage/sqlalchemy/alembic
$ alembic revision -m "migration_description"

Related to blueprint convert-to-alembic

Change-Id: I59cf409106e0ba8bb819f7fc6aeddd0a837fee4c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-10 13:48:24.000000000', 'message': "Make lock_file_prefix optional

Currently, the lock_file_prefix says it should end with an hypen if
specified. It seems that it was intended to be optional. Since that
behavior makes sense, this patch changes the synchronized's signature
and makes lock_file_prefix optional.

With this patch, the prefix will not be required to end with an hypen
anymore, such sign will be added to the prefix if specified and if not
already present.

This patch doesn't change synchronized's behavior at all, which means it
doesn't break backward compatibility.

Change-Id: I8841da1e8d105aac4a86b247228a9c935e00afc5

commit_message:
Make lock_file_prefix optional

Currently, the lock_file_prefix says it should end with an hypen if
specified. It seems that it was intended to be optional. Since that
behavior makes sense, this patch changes the synchronized's signature
and makes lock_file_prefix optional.

With this patch, the prefix will not be required to end with an hypen
anymore, such sign will be added to the prefix if specified and if not
already present.

This patch doesn't change synchronized's behavior at all, which means it
doesn't break backward compatibility.

Change-Id: I8841da1e8d105aac4a86b247228a9c935e00afc5

commit_message:
Add a 0-score for unknown score keys

Will print a warning message - so cron should email the owner of the job
when an unknown score key is encountered.

The example is blueprint db2-database which has "Not" as the priority

Change-Id: I4d43017be6a54bc3322d5aa754034a3d973d484d
Reviewed-on: https://review.openstack.org/36846
Reviewed-by: Jeremy Stanley <fungi@yuggoth.org>
Approved: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>
Reviewed-by: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>
Tested-by: Jenkins

commit_message:
Fix capitalization of VMBuilder and improve wording

The proper capitalization is VMBuilder, let's use that.
Reference: https://launchpad.net/vmbuilder

I've updated this with suggestions by Diane Fleming (thanks!)
to improve the overall section (now really part of this set).

Change-Id: I9912c6e544c49f10f1214eee9c4735d79a2a34f6

commit_message:
Disable mongod prealloc, wait for it to start

No prealloc should make mongod starts faster, and the while loop will
wait it is listening before running the tests.

Change-Id: Ia2ff201c0cfa882aa00bb7ce8ce990525f18339e

Initial implementation of HDP plugin.

Implements blueprint apache-ambari-service-provider

Co-Authored-By: John Speidel <jspeidel@hortonworks.com>

Change-Id: I120c29bc018a229ec89a2b7ddbc553d2848699cb

commit_message:
Port deferredDelete API to v3 Part 2

Ports the deferredDelete extensions and the corresponding unittests
to the v3 framework.

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api

Change-Id: Idc847e1b3c9fb422043d3a919452d842c2c4c30b

subject: Port AttachInterfaces API to v3 Part 2

commit_message:
Port AttachInterfaces API to v3 Part 2

This patch contains the changes required to adapt the AttachInterfaces
extension and the corresponding unittest to the v3 framework

Partially implements: bp v3-api-extension-versioning

Change-Id: I0f3d4da962323a318448634e762f7c31490f9298

'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-06-03 23:17:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-06-10 17:45:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

Most of the implementation looks fine, except for a couple of comments inline and one other issue about where this should be triggered.

The collector is meant to scale horizontally by having multiple copies running. We wouldn't want all of them running the cleanup task. We also wouldn't want the cleanup task to slow down the work of the rest of the collector service. I wonder if it makes sense for the cleanup code to run outside of the collector (in a new service or in a command line tool run from cron)."}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2013-06-10 17:59:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

@doug, I don't think it would slow down the collector that much. I'd rather take a little performance hit than have to manage yet another service."}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2013-06-10 19:30:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

I was thinking more about this over lunch ... this periodic task should emit a Meter whenever the purge is done. This would be a problem with the self-cleansing db's, but very handy none-the-less. 

Doesn't have to go in this branch, but something to consider to follow. CM should be metering CM."}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2013-06-10 22:24:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

i'd be interested to know what happens when multiple cleanups are triggered at the same time."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-06-13 09:18:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: (3 inline comments)

I'm actually agreeing with Doug here, just because we know have an UDP collector; if you don't want to run the collector at all for whatever reason, having this outside is going to be handy.

As for multiple delete, this isn't Ceilometer's problem, doing data safety is a problem with the backend. SQL and MongoDB should be fine with that."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-06-13 11:22:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-13 11:27:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'created': '2013-05-30 09:49:22.000000000', 'message': "Allow to enable time to live on metering sample

blueprint db-ttl

Allow to enable time to live on metering sample

The collector start the metering sample cleanup
process every 'database_clear_expired_data_interval' seconds to
remove sample according the 'database_time_to_live'

If the backend support ttl natively (mongodb >= 2.2 or hbase), the cleanup
fonction in the backend is just a dump, and the backend handle the ttl itself.

If the backend doesn't support ttl at all, it raise a
NotImplementedException catched by collector to fill the log correctly.

commit_message:
Allow to enable time to live on metering sample

The collector start the metering sample cleanup
process every 'database_clear_expired_data_interval' seconds to
remove sample according the 'database_time_to_live'

If the backend support ttl natively (mongodb >= 2.2), the cleanup
function in the backend is just a dump, and the backend handles the TTL
itself.

If the backend doesn't support ttl at all, it will raise a
NotImplementedException caught by collector to fill the log correctly.

Blueprint: db-ttl

Change-Id: I869ce6f50065d0ae8d7095a260efbfcd33165eef

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-02 17:30:31.000000000', 'message': 'File based publisher

Cilometer logs metering data into database by default. In some cases
it is ideal to have the metering data go into a file which can be
examed easily. This patch adds the file based publisher, one can
make changes to pipeline.yaml file to add the file publisher to
an existing pipeline or a new pipeline so that metering data not
only be saved in database but also be saved in a rotating file.

The following example shows how it can be configured in pipeline.

        -
            name: meter_file
            interval: 600
            counters:
                - "*"
            transformers:
            publishers:
                - file:///tmp/meters?max_bytes=10000000&backup_count=5

With the above configuration, a set of files named meters can be
found in /tmp directory. The file names should be meters, meters.1,
meters.2 etc. These files will contain all the metering data. Since the
rotating log file class was used for the implementation, one can increase
the backup_count and max_bytes to keep the file for a longer period or
use the path to point the file to a more permenate location other than
the default directory.

Change-Id: If85ad95f837b2d178527eb7de16707f8af2c4ce2

commit_message:
File based publisher

Ceilometer logs metering data into a database by default. In some cases
it is ideal to have the metering data go into a file which can be
examined easily. This patch adds the file based publisher. One can
make changes to pipeline.yaml file to add the file publisher to
an existing pipeline or a new pipeline so that metering data can not
only be saved in database but also can be saved in a file.

The following example shows how it can be configured in pipeline.

    -
        name: meter_file
        interval: 600
        counters:
            - "*"
        transformers:
        publishers:
            - file:///tmp/meters?max_bytes=10000000&backup_count=5

With the above configuration, a set of files named meters can be
found in the /tmp directory. The file names should be meters, meters.1,
meters.2 etc. These files will contain the metering data. Since the
implementation uses rotating log file when max_bytes and backup_count
are specified, one can increase the backup_count and max_bytes to keep
the file for a longer period or use the path to point the file to a
desired location. If no file path specified, the publisher will log an
error and not record any metering data.

Change-Id: If85ad95f837b2d178527eb7de16707f8af2c4ce2

[{'created': '2013-07-15 23:38:32.000000000', 'message': "Modify startup order of Cinder services.

There are cases where the timing between the start up
for cinder-volume and cinder-scheduler service can result
in a race where the scheduler doesn't know about the volume-service
until the next periodic update.

This change does attempts to do an easy fix by swapping the start
order of the cinder services to ensure that the scheduler will be
able to receive the volume service capabilities update.

Fixes bug: 1189595

Change-Id: I8f477ddc04c15c04493f7ce6863e08e1de8f0128
"}, {'created': '2013-07-16 00:08:53.000000000', 'message': "Modify startup order of Cinder services.

There are cases where the timing between the start up
for cinder-volume and cinder-scheduler service can result
in a race where the scheduler doesn't know about the volume-service
until the next periodic update.

This change does attempts to do an easy fix by swapping the start
order of the cinder services to ensure that the scheduler will be
able to receive the volume service capabilities update.

Fixes bug: 1189595

Change-Id: I8f477ddc04c15c04493f7ce6863e08e1de8f0128
"}]
commit_message:
Modify startup order of Cinder services.

There are cases where the timing between the start up
for cinder-volume and cinder-scheduler service can result
in a race where the scheduler doesn't know about the volume-service
until the next periodic update.

This change does attempts to do an easy fix by swapping the start
order of the cinder services to ensure that the scheduler will be
able to receive the volume service capabilities update.

Fixes bug: 1189595

Change-Id: I8f477ddc04c15c04493f7ce6863e08e1de8f0128

commit_message:
Implement a basic REST alarm notification

This change adds schemes http:// to the alarm notifier.

The URL is called as a POST request.
The body of request contains a json dictionnary with alarm state and the
reason.

Change-Id: I0dbdd6afdef1a88602c9fbc55d651d3d8f6ad3e0
Blueprint: alarm-notifier

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-16 11:10:16.000000000', 'message': 'commit c227446f15c91cd157d60cac1c2f35437df42de9
Author: mathieu-rohon <mathieu.rohon@gmail.com>
Date:   Mon Jun 17 17:56:14 2013 +0200

    Add gre tunneling support for the ML2 plugin

    This patch add the type_driver GRE to enable the creation of GRE
    tunnels with the OVS agent.
    No Endpoints ID are managed. Only Endpoint IP are stored in DB,
    and this IP is proposed as an endpoint ID for the OVS agent.

    It also fixes the bug 1201471

    Implements: blueprint ml2-gre
    Change-Id: I1a33a4bd3ebc4c97eecf17a59ce16b8c2066ec66

Change-Id: I9daecbc039e55b1c963f019428cf4453509b181e
'}, {'created': '2013-07-16 11:18:10.000000000', 'message': 'commit c227446f15c91cd157d60cac1c2f35437df42de9
Author: mathieu-rohon <mathieu.rohon@gmail.com>
Date:   Mon Jun 17 17:56:14 2013 +0200

    Add gre tunneling support for the ML2 plugin

    This patch add the type_driver GRE to enable the creation of GRE
    tunnels with the OVS agent.
    No Endpoints ID are managed. Only Endpoint IP are stored in DB,
    and this IP is proposed as an endpoint ID for the OVS agent.
    It also fixes the bug 1201471.

    Implements: blueprint ml2-gre
    Change-Id: I1a33a4bd3ebc4c97eecf17a59ce16b8c2066ec66

Change-Id: I9daecbc039e55b1c963f019428cf4453509b181e

commit_message:
commit c227446f15c91cd157d60cac1c2f35437df42de9
Author: mathieu-rohon <mathieu.rohon@gmail.com>
Date:   Mon Jun 17 17:56:14 2013 +0200

    Add gre tunneling support for the ML2 plugin

    This patch add the type_driver GRE to enable the creation of GRE
    tunnels with the OVS agent.
    No Endpoints ID are managed. Only Endpoint IP are stored in DB,
    and this IP is proposed as an endpoint ID for the OVS agent.
    It also fixes the bug 1201471.

    Implements: blueprint ml2-gre
    Change-Id: I1a33a4bd3ebc4c97eecf17a59ce16b8c2066ec66

Change-Id: I9daecbc039e55b1c963f019428cf4453509b181e

commit_message:
Cleanup and make HACKING.rst DRYer

Reference the OpenStack hacking guide in HACKING.rst and remove
duplicate entries.  Add section for tempest specific rules.

Change-Id: Idea236dfa7430fb49892c0d677f6f18175c1249d

John Dewey proposed that we remove `knife cookbook test' altogether.

What's the consensus?

To note, `knife cookbook test' seems most useful during development. It will skip checks if files are unchanged.

Example:

DEBUG: Ruby file .cookbooks/openstack-ops-messaging/attributes/default.rb is unchanged, skipping syntax check"}, {'account_id': 216, 'date': '2013-07-16 03:16:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 216, 'date': '2013-07-16 03:16:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Since we dont add a knife.rb in the previous strainer work, I don't think we should here.

If you are developing with chef, it is very very likely one already has a knife.rb on their system.  Again, they may not, but we didn't create this file under Strainer so rather not here, just b/c we have shell."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-16 03:21:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Removed Strainer it is way too slow

I can't use Strainer any longer.  Bundler alone is slow as
it is but strainer is way way too slow, for me to keep my sanity
when writing tests.  Tests under strainer take 3 times longer
than without.  Initial debugging via strace(1) indicate slowness
copying to the sandbox.  I did not spend a ton of time debugging
this, but 3x speed increase seems worth it.  Link to my test results:
  https://gist.github.com/retr0h/f8416fd0c11e185afe37

Change-Id: I089b6e312adbc0ca10ac0b6e522ef580ad6f9923

commit_message:
Fix joint behaviour of Back button and 3-steps Create Service Wizard.

1. Return Back button to the template for 2nd Wizard's step.
2. Restore field values on 2nd step on return from 3rd step.

Fixes: bug MRN-24
Change-Id: I253a15e2f791b14c972cef838f9ffb6697b413c3

commit_message:
Emit cpu_util from transformer instead of pollster

The emission of the cpu_util counter from the compute CPUUtilPollster
can be superceeded by the RateOfChangeTransformer (the intended
target usercase for the new transformer).

The caching of the CPUStats is now no longer required.

Note that the pipeline.yaml must be updated in deployments, otherwise
the cpu_util meter will no longer be collected.

Change-Id: I79ff047595b960de7a2acb2ec81c357fe2ee21e5

[{'created': '2013-07-15 10:31:09.000000000', 'message': "Allow simpler scale exprs in transformer.conversions

For convenience of deployers, allow scale expression to be
expressed as for example:

  100.0 * (10**9 / (resource_metadata.cpu_number or 1))

instead of requiring that the full dict lookup syntax with
default value is used:

  100.0 * (10**9 / resource_metadata.get('cpu_number', 1))

Unknown items evaluate to false in boolean expressions such
as:

  resource_metadata.non.existent or 1.0

commit_message:
Allow simpler scale exprs in transformer.conversions

For convenience of deployers, allow scale expression to be
expressed as for example:

  100.0 / (10**9 * (resource_metadata.cpu_number or 1))

instead of requiring that the full dict lookup syntax with
default value is used:

  100.0 / (10**9 * (resource_metadata.get('cpu_number', 1))

Unknown items evaluate to false in boolean expressions such
as:

  resource_metadata.non.existent or 1.0

Change-Id: I2f1f84641222057b4d6213dcfd1c16f23ae9f273

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-16 11:50:59.000000000', 'message': 'Add "install from directory" to os-svc-install

This will allow elements to install from a directory that has
been downloaded by the source-repositories element.

In cases where this install method is used no attempt is made
to verify the directory being installed from. The assumption is
that the source-repositories element errors if multiple elements
try to download to the same directory. Its also assumed that the
repository version downloaded is correct as this can now be set
by the process running d-i-b and the element shouldn't be aware
of it.

Change-Id: Iceada839f0418789156741b56979c4a287a9a24d
'}, {'created': '2013-07-16 11:50:59.000000000', 'message': 'Add "install from directoy" to os-svc-install

Change-Id: Iceada839f0418789156741b56979c4a287a9a24d
'}, {'created': '2013-07-16 11:50:59.000000000', 'message': 'Add "install from directory" to os-svc-install

This will allow elements to install from a directory that has
been downloaded by the source-repositories element.

In cases where this install method is used no attempt is made
to verify the directory being installed from. The assumption is
that the source-repositories element errors if multiple elements
try to download to the same directory. Its also assumed that the
repository version downloaded is correct as this can now be set
by the process running d-i-b and the element shouldn't be aware
of it.

Change-Id: Iceada839f0418789156741b56979c4a287a9a24d
'}, {'created': '2013-07-16 11:50:59.000000000', 'message': 'Add "install from directory" to os-svc-install

Change-Id: Iceada839f0418789156741b56979c4a287a9a24d
'}]
commit_message:
Add "install from directory" to os-svc-install

This will allow elements to install from a directory that has
been downloaded by the source-repositories element.

In cases where this install method is used no attempt is made
to verify the directory being installed from. The assumption is
that the source-repositories element errors if multiple elements
try to download to the same directory. Its also assumed that the
repository version downloaded is correct as this can now be set
by the process running d-i-b and the element shouldn't be aware
of it.

Change-Id: Iceada839f0418789156741b56979c4a287a9a24d

subject: commit c227446f15c91cd157d60cac1c2f35437df42de9 Author: mathieu-rohon <mathieu.rohon@gmail.com> Date:   Mon Jun 17 17:56:14 2013 +0200
messages: [{'account_id': 2888, 'date': '2013-07-16 11:08:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned\n\ncan't mark a patch as a blueprint implementation and bug fix?"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-16 11:06:17.000000000', 'message': 'commit c227446f15c91cd157d60cac1c2f35437df42de9
Author: mathieu-rohon <mathieu.rohon@gmail.com>
Date:   Mon Jun 17 17:56:14 2013 +0200

    Add gre tunneling support for the ML2 plugin

    This patch add the type_driver GRE to enable the creation of GRE
    tunnels with the OVS agent.
    No Endpoints ID are managed. Only Endpoint IP are stored in DB,
    and this IP is proposed as an endpoint ID for the OVS agent.

    Implements: blueprint ml2-gre
    bug : 1201471
    Change-Id: I1a33a4bd3ebc4c97eecf17a59ce16b8c2066ec66

Change-Id: Ib6bf681a76556aa46f80ad0ac38fd6c262933bc8
'}]
commit_message:
commit c227446f15c91cd157d60cac1c2f35437df42de9
Author: mathieu-rohon <mathieu.rohon@gmail.com>
Date:   Mon Jun 17 17:56:14 2013 +0200

    Add gre tunneling support for the ML2 plugin

    This patch add the type_driver GRE to enable the creation of GRE
    tunnels with the OVS agent.
    No Endpoints ID are managed. Only Endpoint IP are stored in DB,
    and this IP is proposed as an endpoint ID for the OVS agent.

    Implements: blueprint ml2-gre
    bug : 1201471
    Change-Id: I1a33a4bd3ebc4c97eecf17a59ce16b8c2066ec66

Change-Id: Ib6bf681a76556aa46f80ad0ac38fd6c262933bc8

subject: overcloud-source: Fix overcloud parameters.
messages:
[{'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-07-16 09:42:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Two nits; a) metadata proxy is so needed and b) packets will be NATd, which is a form of routing, which makes your commit message misleading in a sense...
 
On consideration, lets use 10.0.0.0/8 for the ovs_range - the only limitation is that instances within that range can't talk to outside networks on that range, but thats much less of a problem than 'I can't ssh to my VM because my internet cafe has the same IP range', which we won't suffer."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-16 09:42:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Change-Id: If7191fa8baf1209ae33b9e8200f52ea0ade97810
'}, {'created': '2013-07-16 09:42:32.000000000', 'message': 'overcloud-source: fix metadata-proxy ovs_range.

These values were missed in the initial overcloud.yaml. Without them
the process does not work. 198.51.100/24 is TEST_NET_2, and that is
appropriate as this is an example and the packets will never be routed.

commit_message:
overcloud-source: Fix overcloud parameters.

These values were missed in the initial overcloud-source.yaml.

nova.metadata-proxy is required to allow vms to communicate with the
EC2-style metadata service.

quantum.ovs.fixed_range constraints DHCP allocation for the undercloud,
but in the overcloud we do not want this constraint because the individual
subnets we define will do that. quantum.ovs.ovs_range configures the
range of ips that can be assigned to the tenant subnets.

Change-Id: If7191fa8baf1209ae33b9e8200f52ea0ade97810

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-21 10:06:37.000000000', 'message': "Add decorator 'action_response' for fixing coverage action return 204

Coverage action 'start' and 'reset' return nothing, so those response code should
be 204. Because it isn't all the actions return same code, so wsgi.response doesn't work.
Add decorator 'action_response', it will change the 'wsgi_code' of function by
request body when executing.

Change-Id: If9f873d85dbb10d9bfd1ae8a7122c3e3d94fc955
"}, {'created': '2013-06-21 10:10:46.000000000', 'message': "Add decorator 'action_response' for fixing coverage action return 204

commit_message:
Fix status code for coverage API v3

* Change the status code of action 'reset' and 'stop' code to 204, and use
'wsgi.action' instead of action method.
* When stop coverage without started coverage will raise HTTPConflict
* Add decorator 'extensions.expected_errors'

Partially implements bp v3-api-extension-versioning

DocImpact

Change-Id: If9f873d85dbb10d9bfd1ae8a7122c3e3d94fc955

commit_message:
Port flavor_rxtx extension to v3 API Part 1

This changeset only copies the v2 files (implementation and test)
into the appropriate v3 directories unchanged. The copy as-is
will not be loaded by either the v2 or v3 extension loaders. The
second changeset will then make the changes required for it to
work as a v3 extension.

This is being done in order to make reviewing of extension porting
easier as gerrit will display only what is actually changed for v3
rather than entirely new files

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api

Change-Id: I560aacfcde07481c2bcc6d8ab4c785ba6e2c2e2b

subject: Porting os-aggregates extensions to API v3 Part 2

commit_message:
Porting os-aggregates extensions to API v3 Part 2

This includes a set of fixes and improvements to os-aggregates:
    - eliminate the action method replacing its functionality with wsgi.action
      decorator.
    - Returns explicity and appropriate status codes for each REST action.
    - Improves information error passed to the user.

In the unit test removes one test that in fact was testing the action method
itself instead of _remove_host and which no longer makes sense since action is
removed.

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api

Change-Id: Ie737333c6b058f5b57b3e7c75b3d3eda95b80402

subject: Porting os-aggregates extensions to API v3 Part 1

commit_message:
Porting os-aggregates extensions to API v3 Part 1

This changeset only copies the v2 files (implementation and test)
into the appropriate v3 directories unchanged. The copy as-is
will not be loaded by either the v2 or v3 extension loaders. The
second changeset will then make the changes required for it to
work as a v3 extension.

This is being done in order to make reviewing of extension porting
easier as gerrit will display only what is actually changed for v3
rather than entirely new files

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api

Change-Id: Idb1fa71371d9a759b5ff2dd70e703aeece84cf5e

commit_message:
Porting server metadata core API to API v3 Part 2

This adapts server metadata API to v3 tree using the new extension
framework.
Partially implements bp v3-api-core-as-extensions

Change-Id: I2013ef255e00e256899f8048c97c1d6c73b3268f

subject: Porting server metadata core api to API v3 Part 1

commit_message:
Porting server metadata core api to API v3 Part 1

This changeset only copies the v2 files (implementation and test)
into the appropriate v3 directories unchanged. The copy as-is
will not be loaded by either the v2 or v3 extension loaders. The
second changeset will then make the changes required for it to
work as a v3 extension.

This is being done in order to make reviewing of extension porting
easier as gerrit will display only what is actually changed for v3
rather than entirely new files

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api

Change-Id: I705336c4bfb66e576e520e8b4293adf45ad63aa8

commit_message:
Add flag argument to 'cinder-manage config list'

Unlike other cinder-manage 'list' commands the 'config list'
option doesn't allow users to specify a filter to limit
the output.  This commit adds the ability to specify
the flag the user wishes to display.

If no flag is specified the default behavior is still to
display all the configured flags.  If the flag requested
is not found, cinder-manage reports that the flag was not
found.

(fixes bug 1187137)

Change-Id: I698f4c06d7e93217d8f307a880e0ae40711151c2

commit_message:
Ensure correct return code of run-tests.sh

If 'kill -9 mongodb_pid' failed, run-tests.sh exit with a
return code of 0.

This change ensure that the return code is the one of the failed
command.

Change-Id: Iad58dac3fa66d1ea688af706940511033c1d76f7

commit_message:
Catch additional connect fail cases.

When fixing bug/1195910, some other failure
cases weren't considered (ie not authorized,
unreachable dest etc).

We should fix this up to handle the various
connection error states accordingly and also
add some hints to the log output to help
determine where to look in case of failure.

Fixes bug: 1201592

Change-Id: Ib099c7af705e7c49be4d0f723c8a20262c942e7f

subject: XenAPI: Attempt clean_shutdown before hard_shutdown
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-21 20:00:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/34031/1/check/gate-nova-pep8/29866 : SUCCESS in 3m 58s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/34031/1/check/gate-nova-docs/24085/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 3m 29s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34031/1/check/gate-nova-python26/25469 : SUCCESS in 20m 35s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34031/1/check/gate-nova-python27/25574 : SUCCESS in 11m 40s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34031/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/25485 : SUCCESS in 52m 08s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34031/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/25191 : SUCCESS in 41m 14s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34031/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/33031 : SUCCESS in 17m 17s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34031/1/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/12171 : FAILURE in 25m 51s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/34031/1/check/gate-nova-pylint/14517 : SUCCESS in 10m 29s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-06-24 09:00:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

In some circumstances clean_shutdown will delay for up to 20 minutes.  This is primarily when the guest has crashed, or the guest kernel prevents a co-operative shutdown (the PV drivers are asked to shut down the connections, but the guest can refuse).

In this case, the code change above will have a 20 minute delay.

This is fixed in upstream XAPI and will allow you to specify your own timeout, as well as allowing hard_shutdown during a waiting call to clean_shutdown."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-24 14:23:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Bob, that's unfortunate.  Is the configurable clean_shutdown in a version of XenServer that can be tested for first, or just in a master branch at this point?"}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-06-24 15:49:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The next version of XenServer, 6.2, to be released "within days" will include a fix that allows you to run hard_shutdown during an ongoing clean_shutdown.

I'm not sure what the right fix is here...

What is the behaviour that you'd prefer?
* Clean shutdown of the guest - with a rare potential delay of 20 minutes waiting for the clean_shutdown to fail before hard_shutdown
* hard_shutdown of the guest in all circumstances
* clean_shutdown with a delay followed by hard_shutdown

I'd probably do clean_shutdown followed by hard_shutdown.  The behavior of XS6.1 and below with a stalled (e.g. bluescreened) guest is that if we do clean_shutdown then 2 minutes later a hard_shutdown the hard_shutdown will return that another operation is in progress - so we could loop on that until hard_shutdown is successful?'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-24 16:07:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm wondering if it would make sense to use the version querying code to handle shutdown differently based on the version of XenServer.  Kind of like check_resize_func_name does.

But polling clean_shutdown a few times until we know that all versions of xen will have failed and then trying a hard shutdown works as well.  I'll have a quick go at them both to see which seems nicer.

I really just want to avoid the hard shutdown in all cases.  We're going to be calling this a bit more often on guests that we want to turn back on later so trying the clean_shutdown is preferable."}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-06-26 08:48:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Note that the version of XenServer with this issue fixed in has now been released - version 6.2.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-06-26 17:43:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think its better to stall for 20 mins doing the clean shutdown than always doing a hard shutdown. Do we not have a way for users to selet the type, like with reboot?'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-06-26 17:51:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-26 18:07:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

So I think I've come up with a way to utilize the 6.2+ capabilities so the 20 minute stall would only happen on older versions.  But testing is getting the better of me atm.

Will push it up in a bit, and break it out and share it wherever this paradigm is used."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-26 18:17:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-26 18:18:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Woops, didn't split it out yet.

But I'd appreciate feedback on if I've gone too crazy with this solution."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-26 19:03:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/34031/2/check/gate-nova-pep8/30333 : SUCCESS in 4m 02s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/34031/2/check/gate-nova-docs/24551/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 3m 15s

"}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-06-27 10:23:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

While the Jenkins issue needs to be addressed, I think this is a good way to go.

How possible is it to extract the timeouts to the config file?
I can imagine that 2minutes for clean_shutdown might not be enough in some cases and rather than guessing at what a good catch-all value is, would a config value be better?'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-27 15:03:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I will extract to a config value.  Are two minutes and 20 minutes good defaults?'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-27 15:53:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-06-27 16:12:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-27 16:33:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-27 16:49:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/34031/4/check/gate-nova-pep8/30492 : SUCCESS in 4m 26s

- http://logs.openstack.org/34031/4/check/gate-nova-python27/26198 : SUCCESS in 10m 38s

- http://logs.openstack.org/34031/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/26535 : SUCCESS in 55m 05s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34031/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/34521 : SUCCESS in 17m 44s

- http://logs.openstack.org/34031/4/check/gate-nova-pylint/15039 : SUCCESS in 11m 12s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-06-27 17:15:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

I'm not sure what I'd like the behavior to be here - i.e. whether we should ever do a hard_shutdown automatically (given the Windows update case...)"}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-07-01 14:36:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

This does seem difficult to do right.  I think clean_shutdown should definitely be preferred, but at some point the hard_shutdown may become necessary unless we can guarantee some level of cooperation between the host and guest.  I think we should continue to make this better as we find ways to do so, but this change at least allows the clean_shutdown in some(most?) cases compared to never trying it.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-07-01 14:37:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-07-01 15:00:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

I'm happy with either the current approach or using the base timeout.

given the people on this review are aware of the status, we can go with this or revert to the earliest patch."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-07-02 16:16:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

hmm, I think we need to just remove that timeout stuff, but we should at least attempt a clean shutdown before doing the hard shutdown.

Interestingly there is a libvirt change just gone up to do this too, including for terminate instance (because of the boot from volume case... where you still need graceful shutdown when you destroy the VM)"}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-07-08 16:27:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Discussion on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/35303/ - we should merge the two approaches and ensure we have a single value / config option / API rather than multiple hypervisor specific options to do the same thing"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-07-16 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-21 19:07:31.000000000', 'message': 'XenAPI: Attempt clean_shutdown before hard_shutdown

power_off should attempt a clean shutdown before performing a hard
shutdown.  Be kind to the guest.

Change-Id: I8d13c0e757154df08855ed43ee5ae4325f3774fc
'}, {'created': '2013-06-26 18:17:59.000000000', 'message': 'XenAPI: Attempt clean_shutdown before hard_shutdown

power_off should attempt a clean shutdown before performing a hard
shutdown.  Be kind to the guest.

Change-Id: I8d13c0e757154df08855ed43ee5ae4325f3774fc
'}, {'created': '2013-06-26 20:42:43.000000000', 'message': 'XenAPI: Attempt clean_shutdown before hard_shutdown

This adds a new shared method used for shutting down an instance for
resize or power_off.

In XenServer < 6.2 a hard_shutdown will fail while a clean_shutdown is
in progress.  The clean shutdown may take up to 20 minutes to timeout in
some circumstances so the hard_shutdown is attempted until it succeeds,
or a timeout is reached.

In XenServer >= 6.2 the hard_shutdown will succeed during a

commit_message:
XenAPI: Attempt clean_shutdown before hard_shutdown

This adds a new shared method used for shutting down an instance for
resize or power_off.

In XenServer < 6.2 a hard_shutdown will fail while a clean_shutdown is
in progress.  The clean shutdown may take up to 20 minutes to timeout in
some circumstances so the hard_shutdown is attempted until it succeeds,
or a timeout is reached.

In XenServer >= 6.2 the hard_shutdown will succeed during a
clean_shutdown so after a 2 minute wait on clean_shutdown the
hard_shutdown is attempted.

Change-Id: I8d13c0e757154df08855ed43ee5ae4325f3774fc

isn't this what six is for (http://pythonhosted.org/six/)?"}, {'account_id': 7850, 'date': '2013-06-26 00:23:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The only part of this review that `six` covers is the shim I put in `utils`. With `six` we could have `from six.moves import xrange as range` instead of `from nova.utils import range`. Other than that, though, the rest of the commit is still relevant.

The `six` module allows you to import the wrapped names but does not monkey patch modules in the same way that eventlet does. Even if it did, we would still need to normalize the use of `range` vs `xrange` as well as account for the fact that they do fairly different things.

If it is important that we use `six` then I will modify this review to use `six` rather than the custom shim in `utils`.

As a side note, I didn't even notice that `six` was in the `requirements.txt`. What's more is that it's only imported into two modules in the entire nova code-base. If py3 compatibility is project goal then it seems like the inclusion of a shim package like `six` should be better known on some of the developer docs to encourage more people to start using it."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-06-26 01:14:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Since we already have six as dependency I would prefer to use it.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-25 13:15:54.000000000', 'message': 'Change `xrange` to `range` for py3 compatibility

Python3 no longer supports the `xrange` builtin because it has
renamed it to range and removed the orignal range, not to mention
the fact that xrange is ugly.

Unfortunately, `range` in Python2 must allocate the entire list
before being used in iteration. This could cause some serious
performance hits if `range` is used with a significant enough
number of elements.

The middle ground is to place a shim in a common location, `utils`
module in this case, and import that into other module as needed.
All `xrange` has been renamed `range` and `range` has become an
alias for `xrange` when running in Python2 environments. This
allows for both Python2 and Python3 to use the method with the
best performance.

Note: There were some cases in which `range` was actually used
to generate a list (mostly for testing purposes). In these
cases the `range` calls are wrapped in `list` calls to provide
the expected list object from the generator returned by `range`.

Fixes: bug #1194497
Change-Id: I37c2fbb82e51cf15eeab584de6942907771ee5de

commit_message:
Change `xrange` to `range` for py3 compatibility

Python3 no longer supports the `xrange` builtin because it has
renamed it to range and removed the orignal range, not to mention
the fact that xrange is ugly.

Unfortunately, `range` in Python2 must allocate the entire list
before being used in iteration. This could cause some serious
performance hits if `range` is used with a significant enough
number of elements.

The middle ground is to use the shim provided by `six`.
All `xrange` has been renamed `range` and `range` has become an
alias for `xrange` when running in Python2 environments. This
allows for both Python2 and Python3 to use the method with the
best performance.

Note: There were some cases in which `range` was actually used
to generate a list (mostly for testing purposes). In these
cases the `range` calls are wrapped in `list` calls to provide
the expected list object from the generator returned by `range`.

Fixes: bug #1194497
Change-Id: I37c2fbb82e51cf15eeab584de6942907771ee5de

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-05-28 19:07:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-05-30 16:26:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Sorry for coming a little look into the review cycle for this, several folks asked me to review in the context of the whole host allocation blueprint

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/whole-host-allocation

My problem I have with the change as it stands is that this is a mandatory isolation model, where as what I wanted to see was an option for a project that has an aggregate available to them to still use the general pool if that's what they want to do.  I was thinking that there would be a scheduler hint that the user could specify for instances that they wanted to isolate.  That would also allow for there to be multiple isolation pools for a project and for a user to chose between them 

Only flagging as a -1 so we can have the debate.  If making this "user defined isolation" breaks your use case then it would be pretty easy to create an alternative filter that meets my use case based on this one - based on the same aggregate metadata

Phil'}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2013-05-31 12:35:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Hi Phil,
thanks for your comments.

The project isolation that this filter offers is imposed by the cloud administrators not selected by users. 
In fact the users will not know where the instances are running.
In my use case I have research projects that can only use a set of compute nodes (not because the hardware offers 
special capabilities but because policy reasons). For these cases the admins map the compute nodes to projects using 
aggregates and this scheduler filter only allows instances from those projects in the defined aggregates.
I believe this is a common use case for private clouds.

I think what you are suggesting is more a option for the "AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation" filter. In this case there 
are a set of compute nodes that can only run instances from a project but this project can also have instances outside 
the aggregate. In the current implementation of that filter the user can't select where the instance will be started 
but can be easily added.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-05-31 16:06:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (2 inline comments)

Hi Belmiro,

I think I agree with you ;-)   If I try to compare the two filters I think we now have:
 
AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation:  Reserves hosts in specific aggregates only for use by selected projects (in effect limits other projects to the subset of the nodes not on those aggregates)
 
 - Controlled Projects can use specific aggregate and any 
   other non-specific aggregate
 - Other Projects can use any non-specific aggregate  
 
 
ProjectsToAggregateFilter:  Constrains projects to specific aggregates.  
   
 - Controlled Projects can use only specific aggregate
 - Other Projects can use any non-specific aggregate  


For Whole Host I want the behavior of AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation with the user also able to say when to use the specific aggregate.

That does make me wonder though if you couldn't also implement what you need via just a configuration option to AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation
to add in effect the "else" part of your filter ?

It seems that we do have two filters that are very close in function, but which use quite different makes for the metadata keys - which is going to be confusing to users and very difficult to manage if someone wants to switch from one filter to the other. 
 
Also a couple of minor nits on variable naming.'}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2013-05-31 18:21:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Hi Phil,
my initial proposal was to extend "AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation" filter with a configuration option (see previews Patch Sets).
But Joe Gordon and especially Russell Bryant suggested to create a new filter instead a configuration option. 
The filters use different configuration metadata keys to be completely independent and not conflict.
Thanks for the inline suggestions. I will update when we agree on this.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-06-04 10:18:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: No score

Hi Belmiro,

What I read in Joe's comment is just that you shouldn't break the existing behaviour by default - he even says that adding a config option would be OK.

I see Russell's comment in the that he code that he doesn't like the config option - but he didn't really respond to your answer to that as far as I can see.

It's not so much the having separate filters or one configurable filter that I'm really hung up on (configuring to pick a specific filter or configuring a more general filter is still configuration) - its the combination of separate but similar filters which very different metadata values that I think will cause most confusion.

If were all agreed that there are three closely related sets of filter behavior here then it feels to me that they should at least use a common set of aggregate metadata."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-06-04 10:19:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Doh - removed my -1 by accident there"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-06-04 18:30:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-06-10 16:53:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (2 inline comments)

Found an additional performance issue with this approach'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-06-11 14:50:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

Replied to one of Joe's comments"}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2013-06-17 20:26:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (3 inline comments)

Hi, 
thank you so much for all your comments.

As a general comment I agree with Phil that this kind of filter can have a performance hit in big environments. But is how the scheduler was designed and probably should be reviewed. There are other filters suffering from the same problem.
The filter cache seems a good idea to me but how can be implemented?

I answer the inline comments.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-06-18 00:08:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (2 inline comments)

I have concerns about the performance too, but as this is an existing issue in other filters, adding a comment in the docstring raising scale concerns seems like a good solution until we have a better general solution to the db calls in filters issue.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-25 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-25 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2013-06-28 08:01:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Restored

Continue the work'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-06-29 01:16:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2013-07-01 20:49:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (3 inline comments)

Once more, thank you so much for your comments.
I will update asap.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-07-08 17:47:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 23:05:13.000000000', 'message': 'Implements complete tenant isolation filter

Gives to the "AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation" scheduler filter
the complete tenant isolation functionality.
If the metadata "filter_tenant_id" is defined in an aggregate,
instances from that specified tenant can only be created on hosts
belonging to that aggregate.

Previously if a host didn't belong to any aggregate or belonged to
an aggregate that didn't define the metadata “filter_tenant_id”
instances from all tenants could be created in the host.”

Implements: blueprint multi-tenancy-isolation-only-aggregates
DocImpact

Change-Id: I40f1c36f7d1364c29a5b97fa6de71db2b09d7b5f

commit_message:
Implements complete project isolation filter

Implements the "ProjectsToAggregateFilter" filter scheduler.
If the metadata "projects_to_aggregate" is defined in an aggregate,
instances from that specified projects can only be created on hosts
belonging to that aggregate.

Implements: blueprint multi-tenancy-isolation-only-aggregates
DocImpact

Change-Id: I40f1c36f7d1364c29a5b97fa6de71db2b09d7b5f

commit_message:
Modify relative paths of lib, elements for packaging.

Scripts test for existence of ../share/diskimage-builder and
fall-back to ../ if not found.

This allows scripts to run unmodified from a packaged installation
or a local archive/repository.

This allows scripts to be used unmodified

Change-Id: I1de32cfa9e29f58c230fe966a631149740913686

commit_message:
Create templated config files

Removes the need for apt package installation for configuration files.

implements blueprint guestagent-mycnf-versioning

Implement extend volume functionality in Rbd

This implements the extend volume functionality for Rbd driver.

Implements: blueprint extend-rbd-volume
Change-Id: I7ddbd0dda742627e959ac672b125555225238030

I'm not so sure about this. I think that if core, whitelist, and blacklist are inconsistent then its preferable to raise an exception (eg core is missing) rather than have an operator believe they have set a blacklist/whitelist setting and have the server ignore this setting.

At the very least we need to log a warning (but I'm not sure this is sufficient)"}, {'account_id': 5174, 'date': '2013-07-12 14:06:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-07-12 14:07:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Automatically re-added by Gerrit trivial rebase detection script."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-12 14:55:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

(1 inline comment)

I agree, maybe throwing an exception if things are inconsistent is better. Seems wrong to silently ignore their settings."}, {'account_id': 5174, 'date': '2013-07-12 21:15:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

so I opted for the log.Warning for two reasons:
 - when black and white lists colide, we accept it anyway, with the black list override the whitelist. So the configuration kind of fails as I propose here.
 - and in the v2 core were always loaded, so if there are core api, if it has no problem to work, I think we have to load it.

next patch in seconds and you guys see what do you think about it'}, {'account_id': 5174, 'date': '2013-07-12 21:15:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-12 22:35:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/36454/5/check/gate-nova-pep8/32716 : FAILURE in 4m 33s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/36454/5/check/gate-nova-docs/26937/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 3m 39s
- http://logs.openstack.org/36454/5/check/gate-nova-python26/28175 : SUCCESS in 24m 24s
- http://logs.openstack.org/36454/5/check/gate-nova-python27/28418 : SUCCESS in 11m 19s
- http://logs.openstack.org/36454/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/31773 : SUCCESS in 1h 02m 44s
- http://logs.openstack.org/36454/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/31466 : SUCCESS in 52m 28s
- http://logs.openstack.org/36454/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-neutron/3148 : SUCCESS in 29m 36s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/36454/5/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/17778 : SUCCESS in 30m 19s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/36454/5/check/gate-nova-pylint/16741 : SUCCESS in 11m 43s (non-voting)
"}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-07-14 07:27:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Looks like there are some pep8 issues with the update.

More broadly I've thought about this patch a bit more and I'm still not convinced a log warning is sufficient. This does differ from the black/whitelist case because it is expected that there will be valid use cases where someone has a whitelist to make sure newly installed modules are not accidentally run and then for specific circumstances (say a security problem is found in a module) adds an entry to the blacklist for a module already in the whitelist.

However it is always a configuration error to place a core module in the black list or fail to place it in the white list. We are never going to honour either request so I think its probably better to just raise an exception and abort.

I won't -1 the concept yet, but I would like to hear input from a wider range of people."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-07-14 23:20:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Yeah, I agree.  I would prefer it just fail if core APIs are in the whitelist/blacklist config"}, {'account_id': 5174, 'date': '2013-07-16 03:48:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Abandoned

since no one agrees with the change, I'm abandonig it"}]

commit_message:
Prevents core API v3 to be black or whitelisted

This removes the influence of blacklist or whitelist against core API v3.
So now a blacklisted core API will load the same, and if the whitelist is set it
will load the extensions whitelisted and the core API.

related to bp nova-v3-api

Change-Id: Ibdd22aa8ed272db04f3e5c95056aec5b352a4086

messages:

Looks good. Given how the metadata update is implemented for WaitConditions (which is afaik the only thing you can update at the moment), I think we should be using PATCH as the method rather than PUT. PUT implies total replacement.'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-06-10 22:48:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-06-10 22:49:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Now using PATCH not PUT. Also the body is parsed as json.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-10 23:42:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/32354/2/check/gate-heat-pep8/3436 : SUCCESS in 1m 30s

- http://logs.openstack.org/32354/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/22048 : SUCCESS in 44m 15s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32354/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/21755 : SUCCESS in 54m 17s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32354/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/29272 : SUCCESS in 25m 39s
'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-06-11 00:28:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

<asalkeld> stevebaker, what is the motivation for  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/32496
 bit worried users should be using stack update instead
 <stevebaker> asalkeld: its the client-side implementation of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/32354/
 <stevebaker> its possible python-heatclient might be a dependency for the heat-cfntools replacement
 <asalkeld> I see, so used on the guest
 <stevebaker> yes, at least initially
 <asalkeld> I guess the problem with this is we could be  fiddling with the definition of the stack and so the  template is not the true representation of the running stack  - which is a problem
  so if someone re-creates the stack from template it is not  the same
  which is an important attribute of stacks
 wait conditions used metadata (but they doen't have to)
 that was an implementation detail
 now that is exposed
 <stevebaker> I see metadata more as runtime state anyway,  and metadata specified in a template is just the initial state
 <asalkeld> well, if you change the cloudformation::iinit thing
 then it is really diffenent
 <stevebaker> the current instance resource implementation  actually ignores the metadata passed in metadata_update, and  takes it from the template again
 each resource can do something different on metadata_update
 <asalkeld> I think we need a different entity, that is going to be confusing"}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-06-11 00:38:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

more chatting:
 
 <stevebaker> SpamapS might have some grand plans in this area, we should wait until he is back from vacation. In the meantime all I want to do is provide a REST equivalent to the current waitcondition api
 <asalkeld> well to me this is not really the same thing as  template::metadata, it is runtime state
 <asalkeld> essentially because we don't have messaging between the guest and engine we scribble stuff into the metadata
 and use that as a crude message queue
 that is broken IMO
 we just need a guest<->engine messaging system
 <stevebaker> yep, when we *design* something it will end up  being quite different, Marconi might be the way to go
 <asalkeld> but if we add that api, we are going to have to support it
 <stevebaker> or guest <-> guest messaging
 <asalkeld> marconi might be the way
 <stevebaker> but who knows when that would be ready. In the short term I'd like to replicate the current waitcondition design, but using native auth, native api and resource types in an OS:: namespace
 <asalkeld> well lets see what the others say, I agree we need something soon. Just cautious of creating an API that is confusing by design"}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-06-11 00:41:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-06-11 00:46:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

just adding back -1 so we can discuss."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-11 01:39:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/32354/3/check/gate-heat-pep8/3439 : SUCCESS in 1m 33s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32354/3/check/gate-heat-python26/3394 : SUCCESS in 3m 59s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32354/3/check/gate-heat-python27/3393 : SUCCESS in 1m 47s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32354/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/22084 : SUCCESS in 42m 36s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32354/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/21791 : SUCCESS in 57m 07s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32354/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/29309 : SUCCESS in 19m 13s
'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2013-06-11 04:08:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

even if Marconi were incubated, there is an eight month waiting period from incubation to Integrated.  I would think we don't want to eight months for a dependency.  During that time our entire approach to this problem could change.  One option to prepare for marconi if that is the path we ultimately choose is to create a v2 api and deprecate the metadata API."}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-06-11 08:41:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I think one middle ground is to make an openstack version of the waitcondition. But not to make general metadata writable by anyone. so have a waitcond post that might continue to use the metadata, but would make it easier for use to move to something else in the future. If we want to have a per-resource read-writable scratch patch we should separate it from the metadata. IMO metadata is part of the template and should not be a general communication mechanism.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-06-11 09:05:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I'm in agreement with asalkeld, since the only thing we allow metadata update for us wait conditions (and that's an internal implementation detail), we should not expose general metadata update via the API - the most obvious (ab)use-case for this will be updating metadata specified for Instance resources in the template, which should be handled via UpdateStack IMHO."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-06-11 10:42:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hmm, I had always assumed that our use of the WaitConditionHandle metadata was the based on what CloudFormation does. Now that I investigate it, I suddenly realise that a WaitConditionHandle is *actually* an S3 bucket!

Interesting.'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-06-12 21:08:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Abandoned

Consensus is to replicate swift's temporary URLs withing heat-api"}]

commit_message:
Implement metadata update REST API call.

Allows metadata for existing resources to be updated.

This provides a native API equivalent to the cfn waitcondition call, but
not limited to updating metadata only on wait handles.

Contributes to Blueprint native-in-instance-tools
Change-Id: I6d5facf1f9a1904438ccef1e97ac3c6394148552

commit_message:
Reinstate architecture binding for nova-bm.

Per bug 1201656 (which this doesn't fix) nova-compute can only run one
bm arch from a single compute host.

Change-Id: I0eabe6e85ed388af111ef503882dfdf7959d8d97

User credentials are required for stack create/update as they are

commit_message:
Only set X-Auth-User, X-Auth-Key on stack create/update.

All heat operations can be performed with only a token.

User credentials are required for stack create/update as they are
stored for later stack operations.

This change prevents credentials unnecessarily being sent over the wire.

Change-Id: I5ad18067c5db8ada9994d131e98f27af70a7ca06

commit_message:
Make the parameter checking consistent.

Make format_parameters() raise CommandError with
the same message. Rather than raise MalformedRequestBody
and then catch that and raise CommandError. This just
simplifies things.

Change-Id: Ic05af32dd916e953e6b162daccc4525cb4734a46

commit_message:
Port limits core API to API-v3 Part 2

This adds and adapts limits API to v3 tree using the new extension framework

Also changed the unit tests were done in v2 to look more like servers and other
API entry points tests.

Partially implements bp v3-api-core-as-extensions

Change-Id: I370e00bda0f8b328c5bd41bb3701ef77fc1d21d1

commit_message:
Reinstate architecture binding for nova-bm.

Per bug 1201656 (which this doesn't fix) nova is constrained to run
one architecture per nova-compute host.

Change-Id: I352f219f3ebb05705adf4bc6815ab738a0599c6b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-03 23:15:30.000000000', 'message': "Don't use deprecated BaseException.message

When running the unit tests, I'd get a warning message:

 /opt/stack/keystone/tests/test_exception.py:151: DeprecationWarning: BaseException.message has been deprecated as of Python 2.6

We shouldn't be using deprecated functions.

This change makes it so the test doesn't use the deprecated member.

Also, test_unicode_message wasn't a test for security error
formatting so moved it to ExceptionTestCase.

Change-Id: I088bf94433baf0f00d3ff8ca63e5f74e9d300cd0
"}]
commit_message:
Don't use deprecated BaseException.message

When running the unit tests, I'd get a warning message:

 /opt/stack/keystone/tests/test_exception.py:151: DeprecationWarning: BaseException.message has been deprecated as of Python 2.6

We shouldn't be using deprecated functions.

This change makes it so the test doesn't use the deprecated member.

Also, test_unicode_message wasn't a test for security error
formatting so moved it to ExceptionTestCase.

Change-Id: I088bf94433baf0f00d3ff8ca63e5f74e9d300cd0

commit_message:
Adding a policy layer for locations APIs

Added a policy layer for the locations APIs of the domain model to
enable the policy checks for image locations changing.

Implements bp: locations-policy

Change-Id: I702723f060f1cc717aca2d99e32d886666c165f8
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

I really like your approach to allow filters run only once per request if data is static during the request.
What I don't understand is what problem will solve allowing the filter run every X instances. Do you have a use case in mind?"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-02 16:59:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi Belmiro,

I don't have a specific use case in mind for running a filter every X instances - it was just trying to point out that the implementation is flexible in that regard (trying to head of a -1 from anyone that could think of a reason to do this ;-)

I think once or once-per-instance are the two real use cases"}, {'account_id': 7537, 'date': '2013-07-05 08:55:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Approach looks sound and flexible enough to account for future use cases.'}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2013-07-05 16:31:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

missing internationalization of strigs"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-05 17:36:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

Unless I'm mis-understanding you the strings you're flagging are debug log statements.

Only user messages (i.e those that are returned in via the API ) are internationalized as far as I know"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-05 17:42:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

My bad - of course they should be changed.  New patch coming.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-07-05 18:07:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-07-05 19:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me
